**_Differences in the Financial Statements of AGHL and the Parent_**

We have accounted for the Tara Transactions using the acquisition method of accounting under IFRS
3, Business Combinations, applying purchase accounting adjustments that resulted, among others, in
the recognition of intangibles (including goodwill) and deferred tax liabilities in our financial
information. Due to the application of the acquisition method of accounting, the Unaudited Interim
Financial Statements of AGHL are not directly comparable to the Audited Financial Statements of the
Parent.

The key differences between the net assets in the consolidated statements of financial position of AGHL
and the Parent as of September 30, 2023 relate to (i) intangible assets and (ii) assets held for sale with
respect to the Retail platform. The financial information for the Parent as of and for the nine months
ended September 30, 2023 is not included in this offering memorandum. With respect to intangible
assets, AGHL has higher intangible assets of £2,401.9 million compared to the Parent, due to the
revaluation of assets and liabilities in accordance with IFRS 3 upon acquisition of the Parent by AGHL.
To acquire the Parent, AGHL issued ordinary shares and hence increased its share capital and share
premium balances. AGHL also has higher non-current liabilities, specifically deferred tax liabilities of
£104.0 million. With respect to held for sale assets, AGHL has higher held for sale assets of £746.3
million compared to the Parent as the result of the revaluation of the intangible assets of the Retail
platform in accordance with IFRS 3 upon acquisition of the Parent by AGHL. Similarly, AGHL also
has higher held for sale liabilities of £65.6 million for associated deferred tax liabilities. Additionally,
AGHL has increased borrowings of £41.5 million in non-current liabilities because capitalized
transaction costs are no longer recognized as a reduction in the liability due to the application of
purchase price accounting.

The current assets (excluding cash) of the Parent are £3.3 million higher than those of AGHL, the
current liabilities of the Parent are £7.7 million lower than AGHL’s and the non-current liabilities of
the Parent are £7.9 million lower than AGHL’s as a result of transactions of the parent entities of the
Parent, up to and including AGHL. Cash and cash equivalents for continuing operations are the same
for both AGHL and the Parent.

xi


-----

The consolidated statements of profit and loss and other comprehensive income of AGHL and the Parent
for the nine months ended 2023 differ in that, relative to the Parent, AGHL has (i) higher amortisation
of intangibles £(32.5) million, (ii) lower finance costs due to the debt fair value adjustments £(23.0)
million and (iii) higher commissions and fees (due to hedge reserves written off on the formation of
AGHL) £(4.8) million. Other immaterial differences relate primarily to IFRS fair value adjustments and
certain operating costs of £3.1 million. AGHL has higher Reported EBITDA of £1.7 million and
Adjusted EBITDA of £3.9 million compared to the Parent, primarily due to hedge reserves written off
on the formation of AGHL less costs held in the intermediary companies between AGHL and the Parent.

The Retail platform is shown as a discontinued operation until completion of the disposal and its
financial performance is excluded entirely from the profit from continuing operations in the financial
information of both AGHL and the Parent for the nine months ended September 30, 2023. The Retail
platform assets and liabilities are included as held for sale until completion of the disposal in the
consolidated statements of financial position of both AGHL and the Parent as of September 30, 2023.

**_Comparability of the Financial Statements_**

_Historic Acquisitions and Disposals_

We have a long-term track record and well-established process for identifying, executing, and
integrating highly accretive acquisitions across many geographies. We have completed or entered into
acquisition agreements for more than 150 acquisitions since our establishment in 2017. We have also
completed or entered into agreements for four disposals during the periods under review. See “—
_Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions and Disposals” and note 11 to the_
Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and note 14 to the 2022 Audited Financial Statements and note
16 to the 2021 Audited Financial Statements for a description of the acquisitions and disposals
completed during the periods under review. As a result, our financial statements may not be fully
comparable between periods.

As a general matter, following an acquisition of a business or group of assets, our results of operations
are impacted by the results of the newly acquired business or operations, the purchase accounting for
the acquisition, any debt incurred to acquire the business or operations and expenditures made to
integrate the newly acquired business or operations which also affects the comparability of our results
with the previous period. In addition to increasing our income through increasing our commission and
fees, we incur certain costs and expenses in connection with any potential or completed acquisition.

_The Retail Transaction_

In September 2023, we announced the merger and disposal of the business carried on by Atlanta
Investments Holdings 3 Limited and its subsidiaries (the “Retail Business”) with Markerstudy Group
Limited (the “Retail Purchaser”), with our shareholders maintaining a minority stake in the combined
business. The transaction values the Retail Business at £1.2 billion. The sale of the entire issued share
capital of Atlanta Investments Holdings 3 Limited to the Retail Purchaser in consideration for cash and
new shares in Venus Topco Limited (the “Retail Transaction”) is subject to the terms of the sale and
purchase agreement in relation to Atlanta Investments Holdings 3 Limited among Nevada Investments
Topco Limited (the “Retail Seller”), the Retail Purchaser, Ardonagh Rocket Investment Holdings
Limited, Tara Topco Limited and Venus Topco Limited dated 15 September 2023 (the “Retail SPA”).
The Retail Transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. As a result
of this merger and the resulting disposal of the Retail platform, in our Unaudited Interim Financial
Statements, we have presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position
as of September 30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or
loss and other comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the
period ended September 30, 2022. We have not restated or represented any other financial information
as of or for any other period for the impact of the Retail Transaction. See “Summary—Recent
_Developments—Retail Transaction” and notes 1 and 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements._

xii


-----

_The Tara Transactions_

In December 2021, we announced a significant new equity investment whereby our two anchor
investors, Madison Dearborn Partners and HPS Investment Partners, agreed to invest capital through
new funds as part of an equity investment of over $1 billion. These investments, made through certain
co-investments by large global institutions through accounts managed by Madison Dearborn Partners
and HPS Investment Partners, increased our Sponsor’s shareholdings and funded minority buy-outs.
Following completion of this transaction (the “Tara Transactions”), the corporate structure of the
Group changed. On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously
reported our results, merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited.
Following this merger, on June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including
the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the
reporting entity for the Group. AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its
incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022. The nine-month period ended September
30, 2022, however, only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the
consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. Accordingly, AGHL’s
results during any period ended in 2022 are not comparable to any other period presented.

We have accounted for the Tara Transactions using the acquisition method of accounting under IFRS
3, Business Combinations, applying purchase accounting adjustments that resulted, among others, in
the recognition of intangibles (including goodwill) and deferred tax liabilities in our financial
information. Due to the application of the acquisition method of accounting, the Unaudited Interim
Financial Statements of AGHL are not directly comparable to the Audited Financial Statements of the
Parent. See “—Differences in the Financial Statements of AGHL and the Parent” above.

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

This offering memorandum contains non-IFRS measures and ratios, including (i) Adjusted EBITDA,
Adjusted EBITDA margin, Adjusted EBITDA Pro Forma for Completed Transactions, Adjusted
EBITDA Pro Forma for Completed and Near Term Transactions, Reported EBITDA and Total Pro
Forma Adjusted EBITDA (collectively, “Adjusted EBITDA-based measures”), (ii) Total Income,
Total Income Pro Forma for Completed Transactions, Pro Forma Income for Completed and Near Term
Transactions and Total Pro Forma Income (collectively, “Total Income-based measures”), and (iii)
capital expenditures, Available Cash, organic growth, management operating cash flow, operating cash
conversion, free cash flow, investment spend, net free cash flow and constant perimeter (together, with
the Adjusted EBITDA-based and Total Income-based measures, the “non-IFRS measures”), that are

xiv


-----

not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. Our non-IFRS measures are defined by us as
set out below.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA” as Reported EBITDA after adding back management reconciling items.
See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Other Consolidated Financial and
_Pro Forma Data.” We also present Adjusted EBITDA by reporting segment._

We define “Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Adjusted EBITDA divided by Total Income expressed as a
percentage.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA Pro Forma for Q4 Growth and Transactions” as Adjusted EBITDA
Pro Forma for Completed Transactions adjusted for Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Growth and Transactions.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA Pro Forma for Completed Transactions” as Adjusted EBITDA
adjusted for Pro Forma for Completed Transactions.

We define “Available Cash” as our total cash and cash equivalents including Retail and excluding
fiduciary funds and restricted cash. Fiduciary cash consists of client money and insurer money in respect
of insurance premiums, return premiums and claims payments due to insurance companies, insurance
brokers and policyholders. Restricted cash consists of cash deposits kept for purposes of solvency and
capital adequacy requirements imposed by the FCA.

We define “capital expenditures” as purchase of intangible fixed assets and purchase of property, plant
and equipment.

We define “constant perimeter” as the perimeter of the Group as of the last day of the previous period.

We define “free cash flow” as (i) company operating cash flow, (ii) total investments, (iii) other nonrecurring costs such as legacy and other costs, (iv) lease payments, and (v) interest on Existing Notes
and Existing Secured Credit Facilities.

We define “investment spend” as (i) transformational hire costs (recruitment costs, sign-on bonuses,
costs of retention and salary incurred during the period of the capacity restriction or covenant, or during
the one year period after the capacity restriction or covenant has ended, less the income generated by
those new joiners during that period), (ii) business transformation costs (realizing synergy benefits from
acquired businesses by reorganizing management and business structures and by implementing new
systems and processes, in reorganizing group structures, in transforming business processes, in
terminating contractual arrangements, and in driving a cost base that is the right size for the Group) and
(iii) project capital expenditures (excluding maintenance capital expenditures and purchases of renewal
rights).

We define “management operating cash flow” as Adjusted EBITDA less business working capital
movement (including movements in net insurer balances, pre-payments, accrued income, other debtors,
accruals, deferred income, accounts payable, certain other creditors and provisions, excluding any
balances relating to management reconciling items, financing and corporation tax) and maintenance
capital expenditure (excluding purchases of renewal rights).

We define “management reconciling items” as transformational hires, business transformation costs,
legacy costs, other costs, regulatory costs, acquisition and financing costs, gain on revaluation of
associate and investments and profit on disposal of businesses.

We define “net free cash flow” as free cash flow, including proceeds from disposals, less M&A, equity
& debt purchases, plus drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility, less financing and associated
costs and regulatory costs.

xv


-----

We define “operating cash conversion” as management operating cash flow divided by Adjusted
EBITDA.

We define “organic growth” as growth (expressed as a percentage) in Total Income for the period (the
“current period”) on a constant perimeter basis as of the last day of the previous period (the
“comparative period”) less any income contribution in the current period of the businesses acquired
in the comparative period for the time that corresponds to the time in the comparative period prior to
their respective acquisitions, as compared to (ii) the Total Income for the comparative period. Organic
growth includes organic income growth of businesses acquired in the comparative period. The organic
growth for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 excludes any contribution of Hemsley Wynne
Furlong.

We define “Pro Forma for Completed Transactions” as adjustments to give pro forma effect to (i)
acquisitions completed during the period and (ii) financing transactions, in each case, as if they had
occurred on the first day of the period.

We define “Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Growth and Transactions” as adjusted to give effect to as Total
Income Pro Forma for Completed Transactions, as adjusted to give effect to (i) all material acquisitions
completed between October 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023, including certain cost and procurement
synergies, and the disposal of AccuRisk following its sale in the fourth quarter of 2023, in each case, as
if they had occurred on October 1, 2022; (ii) organic growth for the three months for the three months
ended December 31, 2023, calculated as the Adjusted EBITDA or revenue contribution, as applicable,
for the three months ended December 12023, less the Adjusted EBITDA or revenue contribution, as
applicable, of the three months ended December 31, 2022, in each case, on a constant perimeter as of
September 30, 2023; and (iii) acquisition synergies and operational efficiencies across the Group.

We define “Reported EBITDA” as total loss for the period after adding back profit after tax from
discontinued operations, finance costs, tax credit, depreciation, amortisation, impairment of nonfinancial assets, profit/loss from disposal of assets, foreign exchange movements, MSA recharge and
dividends.

We define “Total Income” as the sum of commission and fees, other income, investment income and
finance income.

We define “Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA” as Adjusted EBITDA Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Growth
and Transactions to give effect to: (i) Pro Forma for Completed Transactions (post-December 31, 2023),
(ii) Pro Forma for Transactions under LOI, (iii) maturing producer hires and (iv) capacity strategy
enhancements.

We define “Total Pro Forma Income” as Pro Forma Income Pro Forma for Q4 Growth and
Transactions, as adjusted to give effect to: (i) Pro Forma for Completed Transactions (post-December
31, 2023), (ii) Pro Forma for Transactions under LOI, (iii) maturing producer hires and (iv) capacity
strategy enhancements.

For a detailed description of the adjustments made to Adjusted EBITDA and Total Income, see
“Summary—Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Other Consolidated
_Financial and Pro Forma Data” and See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Information and_
_Other Data—Other As Adjusted Income Data of Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited.”_

We present these non-IFRS measures because we believe that they are widely used by securities analysts
and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. The non-IFRS
measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and should not
be considered in isolation or be used as a substitute for an analysis of our operating result as reported
under IFRS. Non-IFRS measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under
IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to net profit/loss for the period or any other

xvi


-----

performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting
principles or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. The non-IFRS
measures have limitations as analytical tools. Some of these limitations are:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or
contractual commitments;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to
service interest or principal payments, on our debts;

- although amortisation and depreciation are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and
amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and certain of these non-IFRS measures
do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our
statements of cash flows;

- they may differ from similarly titled measures presented by other companies;

- some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating Adjusted EBITDA-based
measures, reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made;

- certain Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures include entities
that were not owned by the Group during the entire period presented and are based on
preliminary and unaudited information that may not be fully comparable to the information of
the Group;

- certain Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures include the
impact of transactions that we expect to completed in the near-term but there may be some
uncertainty around the occurrence or timing of completion; and

- the further adjustments made in calculating Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total
Income-based measures are those that management consider are not representative of the
underlying operations of the Ardonagh Group and therefore are subjective in nature.

**_Adjusted EBITDA-Based Measures and Total Income-Based Measures_**

In evaluating Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures, you should be
aware that, as an analytical tool, Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures
are subject to certain limitations. Adjusted EBITDA-based measures are not a measurement of
performance or liquidity under IFRS and you should not consider Adjusted EBITDA-based measures
as an alternative to (i) profit (as determined in accordance with IFRS) as a measure of our performance,
(ii) cash flow for the period as a measure of our ability to meet our cash needs or (iii) any other measure
of performance or liquidity under IFRS. Total Income-based measures should not be considered as an
alternate to our reported commission and fees and other income. We present Adjusted EBITDA-based
measures and Total Income-based measures as we believe that they are a measure commonly used by
investors and are a measure that we use in managing each of our businesses.

Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures are included in this offering
memorandum because we believe that they provide a useful measure of our results of operations;
however, these measures do not constitute measures of financial performance under IFRS and you
should not consider Adjusted EBITDA-based measures or Total Income-based measures as an
alternative to profit, commission and fees or any other performance measure derived in accordance with
IFRS or as a measure of our results of operations or liquidity. Other companies, including those in our

xvii


-----

industry, may calculate similarly titled financial measures differently from us, and therefore such
financial measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies.

The Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures presented in this offering
memorandum are inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. They do not present our reported results
of operations for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, and are not comparable to the Financial
Statements or other financial information included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. In addition,
the Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures do not purport to indicate our
future consolidated results of operations. Our actual results may differ significantly from those reflected
in these Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures. The calculations of
these Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based measures are based on various
assumptions and management estimates, are inherently subject to risks and uncertainties and may not
give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations of any entity prior
to it being acquired by us. The underlying financial information in the Adjusted EBITDA-based
measures and Total Income-based measures may not be prepared on as basis comparable to our
consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this offering
memorandum. Accordingly, none of the Adjusted EBITDA-based measures and Total Income-based
measures should be relied upon when making an investment decision. See also “Risk Factors—Risks
_Related to Our Business and Industry—The unaudited pro forma financial information presented herein_
_is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties.”_

For a reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA-based measures to our profit or (loss) for the period and for
a reconciliation of Total Income-based measures to Total Income, see “Summary Historical Financial

**Our Company**

We are a highly diversified, leading independent insurance broker based in the United Kingdom
(“UK”) operating at scale across numerous segments of the non-life insurance market in the UK and
internationally. We provide a full range of non-life insurance products and related services across
commercial, personal and wholesale insurance. As an insurance distribution intermediary, our business
primarily consists of working with insurers to design, price, and administer insurance-related products
and services, and as such, we do not assume any underwriting or principal risk. From our formation in
2017 to the end of 2023, we have increased our revenue (excluding Retail) by over three times and our
Adjusted EBITDA (excluding Retail) by over five times, due to consistent strong organic growth and
our proven acquisition strategy. The foundations laid over the past five years have provided a platform
for further growth, which has positioned us, pro forma for all material acquisitions and disposals
completed or committed as of November 2, 2023, as a top 10 independent insurance broker and a top
20 insurance broker globally according to Reinsurance News. In September 2023, we announced the
merger and sale of our Retail Business to Markerstudy in a transaction valuing the business at £1.2
billion. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Retail Transaction.” For the twelve months ended
September 30, 2023 and excluding Retail, we generated gross written premiums (“GWP”) of £12
billion, commissions and fees of £1.2 billion, Total Pro Forma Income of £1.6 billion, organic growth
of 11.6%, Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £555.8 million and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
margin of 33%.

We offer a broad range of non-life insurance products in multiple geographies, ranging from higher
value and lower volume bespoke corporate insurance products placed in the London Market, to SMB
business insurance policies. Each aspect of our business is highly diversified with limited concentration
or dependence on any single product, channel, carrier, income producer, or supplier. We combine this
diversified operating model with a highly collaborative culture across the Group to provide our clients,
carriers, and employees with a high-quality product and service offering. We serve a wide range of
clients that include large multinational corporations (“MNCs”), small and medium enterprises
(“SMEs”), individual consumers, and other third-party brokers and managing general agents
(“MGAs”).

We distribute our insurance products across multiple channels, including through a network of over 120
local offices in the United Kingdom and more than 150 offices worldwide, and online. Our global
network provides the basis for deep, embedded local relationships and “trusted advisor” status with
clients and benefits from long-standing trusted insurer partner relationships. We also maintain regional
hubs to support our businesses through shared resources and expertise.

Following the signing of the Retail Transaction, we have taken steps to organize our business into two
main reporting segments, which we refer to as platforms, that focus on distinct but complementary
aspects of the insurance brokerage and services value chain. See “Summary—Recent Developments—
_Retail Transaction.”_

Following our creation in 2017 as the result of a combination of long-established leading insurance
broking brands, we have rapidly grown into a top 20 global insurance broker by revenue.

**_Scaled platform with significant diversification across geographies and capabilities_**

Our business is highly diversified across products, customers, channels, geographies and carriers. We
offer a wide-ranging product portfolio across both general and bespoke insurance products and services
across the insurance value chain, including personal and commercial lines, wholesale distribution,
underwriting and insurance outsourcing services to large corporations, insurers, third-party brokers,
SMEs, and individual consumers at a variety of price points, without assuming any underwriting or
principal risk in relation to any of the services or products that we provide. For the twelve months ended
September 30, 2023, no single line of business accounted for more than 20% of GWP. We reach
customers through diverse distribution channels, including through our digital platform, telephone
contact centers, and traditional face-to-face customer contact via our network of over 150 offices
globally.

As a result of our international presence, our GWP is diversified by geography, with 66% of our
premium (excluding the Retail Transaction) placed outside the UK (specifically, 30% of our premium
is placed in North America and 15% is placed in Europe). We have long-standing partnerships with key
carriers, and relationships more broadly with a wide range of insurance carriers in each of the markets
that we serve. Our large number of carrier relationships mitigates potential carrier concentration risks
and enables us to enhance and improve our product offerings for clients as well as pricing and our own

Our highly diversified offering ensures minimal reliance on any particular product, distribution channel,
customer, or market, limiting our exposure to any adverse industry developments and macroeconomic
factors and thereby mitigating volatility in our overall financial performance. In addition, the breadth
of our offering provides us with various avenues through which we can identify gaps in the market and
develop specialized products to capture unmet demand. We are thus able take advantage of cross-selling
opportunities to increase our customer penetration and drive incremental growth.

**_Robust, accelerating organic growth benefitting from the realization of key strategic initiatives_**

We have a track record of delivering strong organic income and margin growth. By leveraging our
scaled platform and best practices, we have negotiated superior terms with insurer counterparties,
industry participants, and suppliers, enabling us to offer a better experience and pricing to our
customers. We also value diversity and keeping up with current technologic trends, prioritizing
investments in people and data and technology. As a result, we have grown the business every quarter
(compared with the prior year period) since our establishment in 2017 and have achieved double-digit
organic growth since 2021, growing 10.2% in 2021, 12.5% in 2022 and 11.6% (excluding Retail) in the
twelve months ended September 30, 2023. Our organic growth is driven, in part, by our key strategic
initiatives across our segments, as outlined below.

_Global P&C: UK Advisory_

- _Drive new business: Targeting large corporate clients with focused expertise and leveraging_
data and single customer view to cross-sell products within Advisory and between platforms

- _Enhanced placement: Reducing the number of markets from 750 to 185 to improve client_
outcomes and reduce costs, giving partners white label access to existing binders and
specialties, which allows them the opportunity to re-brand such binders and products, and
leveraging increased scale to increase commission rates paid by customers across business

- _Grow our digital proposition: Enhancing our online offering to improve the customer journey_
and reduce costs, and entering into affinity partner deals

- _Integration:_ Focusing on integration through significant new opportunities for value creation
with rapid integration of further “add-on” accretive acquisitions

_Global P&C: International Advisory_

- _Identify strategic markets: Focusing on select regions that fulfill our acquisition criteria and_
clearly focus on larger, more sophisticated markets with growing macroeconomic conditions
and a developed regulatory environment

- _Utilize networks:_ Leveraging our networks and the wider broker networks to identify suitable
assets and targeting attractive off-market opportunities at below market multiples

- _Realize synergies:_ Rapidly integrating acquisitions to realize significant cost and revenue
synergies

- _Roll-out best practices: Establishing initiatives to accelerate organic growth and improve_
margin and cash flow conversion, and to provide access to new products and capacity

_Specialty Broking_

- _Producer hires:_ Driving existing producer hires to maturity and hiring new individuals who can
add value quickly with a relentless focus on renewal retention, leveraging existing retail and
wholesale relationships

- _Digital solutions:_ Leveraging and overlaying external tools to attract new business and protect
existing business, employing digital solutions to get us closer to our end client

- _Portfolio & Placement:_ Engaging with Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) for select lines
such as terrorism, financial institution, personal injury and cyber in order to increase

- _Global strategy: Maximizing inflow from growing Global P&C platform, leveraging network_
memberships to increase existing business and inflow and capitalizing on footprint to drive
further growth

Our organic growth has been further supported over the past five years by delivering value from our
new producer hires. We have generated Adjusted EBITDA of approximately £30 million for the twelve
months ended September 30, 2023 from 29 maturing producer teams hired since 2020. Teams typically
mature to their full profitability potential approximately three years after the expiry of capacity or
covenant restriction. We have seven teams hired in 2020 that were at 75% maturity as of September 30,
2023, seven teams hired in 2021 at 58% maturity as of September 30, 2023, seven teams hired in 2022
at 37% maturity as of September 30, 2023 and eight teams that started trading in the nine months ended
September 30, 2023. As a result, we expect to realize additional Adjusted EBITDA as a result of these
hires over the next three years.

We have built our Global P&C franchise by building on our UK Advisory business and carefully
selected regional platforms. We have built our Specialty Broking business by investing in carefully
strategic producer hires and specialisms. In the past three years, we have expanded our addressable
markets through acquisitions in new synergistic geographies. In 2020, we acquired our first non-UK
business, Arachas, Ireland’s largest commercial insurance broker, which kick-started our international
operations. We have since established our latest standalone platform, International Advisory, under
which we are consolidating our non-UK broking enterprises and related investments and under which
we have launched our Ardonagh Europe and our Ardonagh Global Partners businesses. We established
Ardonagh Global Partners in 2021 to invest in leading platforms operating in attractive markets and
verticals outside the UK and Europe and to partner with management teams who want to grow faster as
part of a larger group while retaining operational independence. Since its inception, Ardonagh Global
Partners has grown to include various brands, including Resilium, one of Australia’s largest
independently owned intermediary networks and the founding business of our Australian platform and
Ethos Broking Australia, which invests in or directly acquires brokers. We continue to have a robust
M&A pipeline, and we continue to explore larger transaction opportunities both in the UK and
internationally with a strong focus on market-leading platforms in our international business.

To successfully complete and integrate such a large amount of acquisitions, we follow a clear,
disciplined and highly selective acquisition strategy. We encourage competition between segments in
order to receive centrally controlled capital for acquisitions, and we employ a rigorous due diligence
process that is implemented by our highly experienced and dedicated team of investment professionals.
Given the scope of our operational footprint, we are also able to leverage deep local knowledge in our
markets in order to further understand our targets. Our primary focus when reviewing potential
opportunities is on the customer proposition and financial returns. We have also implemented a robust
and efficient integration and post-deal tracking process after closing.

8


-----

Our disciplined execution focuses on a clear, orderly and highly selective strategy based on ten
principles: strategic fit, cultural fit, integration commitment, aligned incentives, financial returns,
synergy discipline, cash discipline, realistic plan, risk assessment and clear accountability. We perform
a rigorous due diligence process through a highly experienced and dedicated team of investment
professionals, leveraging deep local knowledge in the markets where we operate and a robust and
efficient integration and post-deal tracking process. We are able to present ourselves as the acquirer of
choice by emphasizing our culture, aligning interests and maintaining discipline. In addition, we have
made significant investments in our technology platform, which allows us to integrate new acquisitions
at low cost and with low integration risk.

**_Leading data and analytics capabilities driving platform efficiencies_**

Our leading centralized data and analytics capabilities allow us to enhance risk solutions for capacity
providers and improve outcomes for our clients and to drive cost savings. These capabilities have been
primarily utilized to support the building of broker facilities, which then allow us to access
predominantly traditional capacity in more efficient ways for the client. For example, we have used data
and analytics to significantly improve and re-package older previous products into better terms, cover
and product for our clients, including improvements on the Terrorism, Fine Art Jewellery and Specie
facilities. We have also used data and analytics to introduce brand new facilities to the market, such as
a Construction facility and a cross-class facility named LECTIO. The following chart shows our
centralized data analytics structure, where we have centralized global premium and carrier information
using our data center based in Mullingar, Ireland.

As an example, in our Specialty Broking platform, we have built facilities such as the Ardonagh
Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business to use data analytics and capabilities to bring benefits to both
clients, in terms of wider market placement, and our Group, in terms of increased revenues.

Our technology and scale facilities have also allowed us to identify cost savings totalling approximately
£15.8 million that we expect to achieve within the next 12 months. In our Global P&C: UK Advisory
segment, we expect cost savings of £3.2 million, primarily as a result of a target model implementation
project that has reduced headcount through efficiency gains from optimizing policy administration

acquisitions into our existing platforms. In our Specialty Broking segment, we expect cost savings of

**Our Strategies**

**_Accelerate organic growth by optimizing placement strategy and driving new business through new_**
**_products, cross-selling and up-selling_**

We seek to consistently achieve double-digit organic growth across our overall business by expanding
product portfolios, streamlining operations, increasing penetration of our customer base—particularly
in new synergistic geographies—through concerted sales efforts across our Group and capitalizing on
a targeted acquisitions pipeline. We have a growing pipeline of new specialist products that is highly
complementary to our existing offerings, including high net worth, political violence, specialty
terrorism facility. These products are being developed on existing systems and channels at limited
upfront cost and are largely linked to new hires, who can contribute the relevant product and channel
expertise. As an example, new products launched in our Specialty Broking platform contributed towards
organic growth of approximately 11.6% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023.

As part of our organic growth strategy, we are also focused on cross-selling and up-selling and customer
retention and expansion. We seek to improve cross-selling and up-selling across Group clients,
including by leveraging data. We have rolled out of a Group-wide database in which we collate data
from each of our platforms to enable a “single view of the client” (i.e., how many policies are linked to
each client across personal and commercial lines) to facilitate retention, cross-selling and up-selling.
This database continues to provide a more granular understanding of our clients’ needs, allowing us to
offer them tailored cross-selling opportunities. We have also implemented a bespoke pricing system
and leveraged our data infrastructure, fraud detection capabilities and access to third-party data sources
to improve retention and increase customer lifetime value across most products. In our Specialty
Broking platform, we have developed a highly sophisticated customer and broker-facing software
which interfaces with several market-leading policy administrative systems and substantially improves
ease of access to customer and broker data. We are also in discussions with several third-party brokers
who are clients of our wholesale platform to roll-out this software in order to maximize efficiency and
centralization within our platform and improve the experience of third-party brokers on our platform.
We also intend to leverage our membership of the Worldwide Broker Network to increase existing
business and in-flow through the establishment of new relationships and intend to capitalize on our
existing global footprint to drive further growth. In the UK, our UK Advisory business launched a
focused client strategy aimed at large UK corporates, which is already bearing fruit with the successful
signing of several marquee clients, including a global broadcaster that has a £5 billion turnover and also
the UK’s largest charity.

In addition, in 2021, we launched Inver Re, a new risk strategy and reinsurance broker with ambitions
to harness our scale, resources and reach to offer a credible alternative to global brokers and become
our industry’s independent reinsurance broker of choice. We plan to further strengthen our reinsurance
operations by (i) consolidating our existing reinsurance operations while organically building out our
brand, talent and capabilities in key global hubs (such as London, North America & Bermuda), (ii)
developing our first party business through leveraging key group carrier relationships, (iii) hiring
industry leading talent and building further revenue streams and (iv) deploying M&A to expand
geographic focus beyond key hubs (such as in Latin America and Asia).

**_Streamline operations through our continued focus on capacity excellence, talent excellence and_**
**_operational excellence_**

We are constantly re-examining our operating models to incrementally streamline lower value-add
operations and further support our front-office distribution and client service capabilities. We have
developed a range of strategies to streamline operations and optimize middle and back-office functions.
Our strategy is based on three key pillars of excellence, which are:

- _Capacity excellence. We seek to reach capacity excellence by operating a strategic capacity_
model through our Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business, part of our Specialty
Broking platform. APS utilizes data captured from across the Group’s platforms and businesses
to enhance income through a centralized placement. We expect our APS business to be a key
growth driver going forward by allowing us to capitalize on a select number of strategic carrier
relationships, create market leading products which offer better terms for our customers and
access alternative capital providers either directly or in connection with our MGA business. We
intend to engage with APS for select high-profitability lines and actively manage the portfolio
to reduce exposure to underperforming lines.

- _Talent excellence. We believe that we will be able to deliver significant incremental income_
and EBITDA growth by nurturing talent excellence. We are working to attract the best people
in our industry and are ideally placed to capitalize on market dislocation. We believe that
incoming hires bring capabilities and are highly accretive. We have a strong track record of
income hires and producer recruitment, delivering significant incremental income and
EBITDA. We intend to leverage our success to date to continue selective transformational hires,
focusing on hiring exceptional individuals who can swiftly add value to our Group. Since 2019,
we have secured at least five new specialist team hires per year, and currently have a deep
pipeline of future hires. We also intend to deliver on exceptional existing hires, relentlessly
focusing on renewal retention, leveraging existing retail and wholesale relationships.

- _Operational excellence. We believe that through operational excellence we can continue our_
track record of delivering value through our focus on operational expertise. We have delivered
cost efficiencies to drive margin expansion across all divisions, resulting in approximately £150
million of synergies and cost savings delivered to date since the start of 2018, and £15.8 million
of cost savings and cost synergies expected to be delivered within the next twelve months,
consisting of (i) £3.2 million within the UK Advisory platform resulting from benefits from a
target operating model implementation project that has reduced headcount through efficiency
gains from optimizing policy administration systems, IT transformations from improving the
office network, removing legacy applications and outsourcing and an onshoring finance project
expected to deliver benefits from process efficiencies and automation, (ii) £8.2 million within
the Specialty Broking platform resulting from the technology-led transformation of our middle
and back office functions and the cost synergies identified with the acquisition of Corant
Global, including the harmonization of reward structures, footprint consolidation and backoffice optimization, as well as the acquisition of Oxford Insurance, (iii) £3.9 million within the
International Advisory platform through the ‘hub and spoke’ model and the integration of
further acquisitions into existing platforms and (iv) £0.5 million through back-office
optimization in our Corporate segment.

We also continue to make significant investments into our technology platform, as we believe that
digital solutions will get us closer to our end client, allowing us to leverage and overlay external tools
to attract new business and protect existing business.

Ardonagh Global Partners businesses. We established Ardonagh Global Partners in 2021 to invest in
leading platforms operating in attractive markets and verticals outside the UK and Europe and to partner
with management teams who want to grow faster as part of a larger group while retaining operational
independence. We intend to continue growing our International Advisory platform with the aim of
consolidating our presence in a selected portfolio of fast-growing markets and expanding participation
in select new products and markets where there is significant synergy between our UK platforms and
our International Advisory platform. We are focusing on a number of regions which fulfil our
acquisition criteria, and intend to employ the hub and spoke methodology to quickly expand our
regional presence. Our aim is to develop a number of regional hubs, with specialist knowledge,
technology and product expertise, to support in-country assets, and we intend to focus on strategic
markets with assets that are capable of executing further in-country expansion.

**_Continue to grow by capitalizing on targeted acquisitions pipeline_**

As part of our strategy, we target additional growth expected from accretive acquisitions, and intend to
further strengthen our position and broaden our portfolio by continuing to consolidate smaller players
in the highly fragmented and competitive UK and international insurance markets. Any acquisition we
pursue will be in line with our targeted and selective acquisition criteria focused on companies with
attractive profitability, growth potential and complementary business operations. We utilize our
network to identify suitable targets at reasonable multiples. We support acquired assets post-acquisition
in order to achieve our organic growth plans going forward, utilizing our expertise and networks. We
also manage the realization of identified revenue and cost synergies on an ongoing basis. We have a
highly disciplined and proven acquisition program, which includes a standardized approach to
integration and synergy delivery, which, together with the proven execution ability of our management
team and our strong focus on value creation and financial metrics, allows us to maximize synergies and
rapidly deploy economies of scale to acquired businesses.

We have a robust M&A pipeline underpinned by a rigorous evaluation and assessment process driven
by an experienced and dedicated team of M&A professionals, and we continue to explore larger
transaction opportunities both in the UK and internationally with a strong focus on market-leading
platforms in our international business. Acquisitions completed during the fourth quarter of 2023
(including the impact of the AccuRisk disposal) contributed Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £13.6
million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, and acquisitions completed between January
1, 2024 and February 1, 2024 contributed an additional £3.0 million. We have a further 36 acquisitions
that are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent as of February 1, 2024, which would
contribute an additional £32.2 million of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Our pipeline includes targets
on multiple continents. We are also actively pursuing other acquisitions in the near-term or very nearterm, including one or more potentially material acquisitions.

**Recent Developments**

**_Retail Transaction_**

In September 2023, we announced the merger and disposal of the Retail Business with the Markerstudy
Group Limited (the “Merged Business”), with our shareholders maintaining a minority stake in the
Merged Business. The transaction values the Retail Business at £1.2 billion and will be funded by a
new investment led by Pollen Street Capital and Bain Capital Special Situations. We expect to receive
upfront cash consideration of up to £820 million (on a debt free/cash free basis, excluding transaction
fees and expenses, and deferred cash consideration linked to related investments) and an approximately
£400 million promissory note receivable from a related-party entity (“RP Entity”). The RP Entity is
wholly owned by our shareholders and will, with Retail management, receive a 23% equity stake in the
Merged Business. The promissory note receivable to be entered into in connection with the completion
of the Retail Transaction will accrue interest at a fixed rate of 15% (compounding annually), which will
be mandatorily prepaid on any realization of the stake in the Merged Business or a change of control of
the RP Entity, and will require the RP Entity not to incur debt, grant security or make distributions

14


-----

without the consent of our Group. We expect to distribute this promissory note receivable to a parent
entity of the Parent following the completion of the Retail Transactions. In addition, certain exiting
managers will continue to hold shares in management incentive plans within the Group following the
completion of the Retail Transactions, and we will buyback such manager’s shares upon exit or
otherwise winding up such plan.

The Retail Transaction is subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including customary
regulatory and antitrust approvals from both the FCA and the CMA. We expect completion of the Retail
Transaction to occur in the second or third quarter of 2024. The Retail Transaction is subject to
customary transaction risks, including of delay due to longer than expected regulatory reviews or
actions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—The Retail Transaction may
_be delayed or may not proceed to completion.”_

As a result of the Retail Transaction, in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements, we have presented
Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position as of September 30, 2023 and
as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive
income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the period ended September 30, 2022.

We expect a significant portion of the cash proceeds from the Retail Transaction will be applied, subject
to certain exceptions and limits, in mandatorily prepaying at par a portion of our New Senior Secured
Credit Facilities. More generally, we expect the Retail Transaction to release capital to invest in our
higher-growth Specialty Broking and our Global P&C Platforms. See also “Business—Retail—Retail
_Transaction.”_

If the Retail Transaction does not proceed to completion, our ratio of as adjusted total net debt to Total
Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA would be 5.8x, as calculated by adjusting as adjusted total net debt to
remove the net proceeds from the Retail Transaction, including Retail Total EBITDA, and adding Lease
Liabilities associated with the Retail Divestiture.

**_Recent Acquisitions and Disposals_**

We completed 16 acquisitions between October 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023 and have completed 6
acquisitions from January 1, 2024 to February 1, 2024. Notable acquisitions during this period included:

- Assepro, one of the largest independent commercial brokers for SMEs in Switzerland, with
further operations in Austria and Liechtenstein. Assepro places CHF1.2 billion of premium
annually and further strengthens Ardonagh International’s presence across Europe.

- RiskSTOP Group, a provider of insurance technology and risk management services to UK
insurer and broking communities. The acquisition is highly complementary to Ardonagh UK
Advisory’s existing digital client offering.

- London Australia Underwriting (“LAUW”), an underwriting agency specializing in
professional and financial lines exclusively on behalf of Lloyd’s of London syndicates. This
extends agency coverage in Australia and further diversifies Ardonagh International Advisory’s
Australian platform.

Additionally, 36 acquisitions are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent across Europe,
Australia, the UK, Brazil and Ireland as of February 1, 2024.

In December 2023, we disposed of the subsidiaries of Alpha Investment Holdings Limited, which
includes the AccuRisk Solutions LLC group of entities. They were acquired by Ryan Specialty, an
international specialty insurance firm.

**_The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities_**

The Company, among others, as of the date of this offering memorandum, is in the proceeds of
negotiating and expect to establish, new additional facilities under its credit facility agreement dated as
of June 26, 2020, among the Company and, among others, the administrative agent and the lenders party
thereto (as amended and/or restated from time to time, the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities
**Agreement”) governing a multi-currency senior secured term loan facility of up to £2,006 million**
(equivalent), split into a U.S. dollar-denominated Facility B of up to £1,200 million (equivalent) (the
“USD Term Facility”), a euro-denominated Facility B of up to £696 million (equivalent) (the “EUR
**Term Facility”) and a Australian dollar-denominated Facility B of up to £111 million (equivalent) (the**
“AUD Term Facility” and together with the USD Term Facility and the EUR Term Facility, the “New
**Term Facilities”) and senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount**
of $175 million, a senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of
€165 million and a senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of
AUD 100 million (collectively, the “CAR Facility”). We are, as of the date of this offering
memorandum, in the process of negotiating, and expect to amend, our existing multi-currency new
revolving credit facility to provide for borrowings of between £240-300 million (equivalent) (the
“Revolving Credit Facility” and together with the New Term Facilities and the CAR Facility, the
“New Senior Secured Credit Facilities”).

The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Shared
Collateral and guaranteed by the Guarantors on a senior basis. See “Description of Other Indebtedness
_and Financing Arrangements—Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement.” Proceeds from the New_
Term Facilities will be used to repay the outstanding drawings under the Senior Secured Facilities
Agreement on or about the Escrow Release Date. See “Use of Proceeds”. To the extent we do not
receive the required third-party consent required to refinance the Australian Local Facility, we may not
fund the AUD Term Facility and the Australian Local Facility may remain outstanding.

**_Existing Notes Redemption_**

In addition, on or about the Escrow Release Date, the Issuer will use a portion of the proceeds of the
Notes to redeem and/or satisfy and discharge all obligations outstanding under the indenture governing
the Existing Notes by paying the applicable redemption price of the Existing Notes plus accrued and
unpaid interest thereon to the date of redemption (the “Existing Notes Redemption”). See “Use of
_Proceeds”._

The entry into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, the Offering, the entry into the
Intercreditor Agreement and the application of the proceeds from the Senior Secured Credit Facilities
Agreement and the Offering are collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the
“Transactions.”

Escrow Account

Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the initial purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of
the Notes into escrow accounts (the “Escrow Accounts”) in the names of the respective Issuers, but
controlled by the Trustee, Ankura Trust Company, LLC, as escrow agent (in such capacity, together
with its successors, the “Escrow Agent”) pending funding under the New Term Facilities as described
under as described in “—Recent Developments—The Refinancing,” and pledged on a first-ranking basis
in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the respective series of Notes. The release of the
escrow proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. If the conditions to the release
of the escrow proceeds have not been satisfied on or prior to March 31, 2024 (the “Escrow Longstop
**Date”) or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory**
redemption as described under “—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” The special
mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the

**Our Sponsors**

HPS Investment Partners is a leading global investment firm that seeks to provide creative capital
solutions and generate attractive risk-adjusted returns for our clients. We manage various strategies
across the capital structure that include syndicated leveraged loans and high yield bonds to privately
negotiated senior secured debt and mezzanine investments, asset-based leasing and private equity. The
scale and breadth of our platform offers the flexibility to invest in companies large and small, through
standard or customized solutions. At our core, we share a common thread of intellectual rigor and
discipline that enables us to create value for our clients, who have entrusted us with approximately $108
billion of assets under management as of December 2023.

Madison Dearborn Partners, LLC (“MDP”), based in Chicago, is a leading private equity investment
firm. Since its formation in 1992, MDP has raised eight funds with aggregate capital of approximately
$28 billion and has completed investments in more than 160 companies. MDP invests across a broad
spectrum of industries, including: technology and government; basic industries; financial and
transaction services; and health care. A flexible investment approach, encompassing both buyout and
growth equity investments and a focus on upper middle market and middle market companies have
been and continue to be key tenets of MDP’s investment strategy.

 U.S. Federal Income Taxation of OID ... If the stated principal amount of a series of Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount greater than or equal to a statutorily defined de minimis amount, then such Notes will be considered to be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes in an amount equal to the excess of the stated principal amount over the issue price of such Notes. If Notes are issued with OID, a holder of such Notes subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) for U.S. federal income tax purposes as it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis), in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such OID, irrespective of such holder’s regular method of tax accounting. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations— Original Issue Discount.”

**SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA**

_On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously reported our results,_
_merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, on_
_June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that_
_were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the reporting entity for the Group._
_AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its incorporation on December 8, 2021_
_to December 31, 2022. The nine-month period ended September 30, 2022, however, only includes four_
_months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the_
_timing of the Tara Transactions. Accordingly, AGHL’s results during any period ended in 2022 are not_
_comparable to any other period presented. We have accounted for the Tara Transactions using the_
_acquisition method of accounting under IFRS 3, Business Combinations, applying purchase accounting_
_adjustments that resulted, among others, in the recognition of intangibles (including goodwill) and_
_deferred tax liabilities in our financial information. Due to the application of the acquisition method of_
_accounting, the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements of AGHL are not directly comparable to the_
_Audited Financial Statements of the Parent. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Differences_
_in the Financial Statements of AGHL and the Parent.”_

_To aid comparability between periods, the_ _following summary historical (i) consolidated statement of_
_financial position as of December 31, 2022 and the consolidated statement of profit or loss and_
_consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2022 have been derived from_
_the 2022 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent which have been prepared in accordance with_
_IFRS and are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, (ii) consolidated statement of profit or_
_loss and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2021 have been derived_
_from the 2021 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent which have been prepared in accordance_
_with IFRS and are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, (iii) consolidated statement of_
_financial position as of December 31, 2021 have been derived from the comparative column in the_
_2022 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent, due to the restatement of trade and other receivables_
_and retained losses, (iv) consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2020 and the_
_consolidated statement of profit or loss and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended_
_December 30, 2020 have been derived from the comparative column in the 2021 Audited Financial_
_Statements of the Parent and (v) consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of_
_financial position, and consolidated statement of cash flows as of and for the period ended September_
_30, 2022 and the nine months ended September 30, 2023 have been derived from the Unaudited Interim_
_Financial Statements of AGHL which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 and are included_
_elsewhere in this offering memorandum._

_In addition, in September 2023, we announced the Retail Transaction. As a result of this merger and_
_the resulting disposal of the Retail platform, in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements, we have_
_presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position as of September_
_30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other_
_comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the period ended_
_September 30, 2022. We have not restated or represented any other financial information as of or for_
_any other period for the impact of the Retail Transaction. See “Summary—Recent Developments—_
_Retail Transaction” and note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements._

_Financial information of AGHL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 presented in the_
_following summary historical consolidated financial information was calculated by taking the results_
_of operations for the three months ended December 31, 2022 and adding it to the results of operations_
_of AGHL for the nine months ended September 30, 2023._ _The results of operations for the three months_
_ended December 31, 2022 extracted from the accounting records of AGHL have been adjusted to_
_present Retail as a discontinued operation for the purposes of calculating the financial information for_
_the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 presented herein. See “Presentation of Financial_
_Information—Comparability of the Financial Statements—The Retail Transaction.” The financial_

(4) We define profit from disposal of assets as the disposal of property, plant and equipment, right-of-use assets and intangible assets.

(5) We define foreign exchange movements as gains/losses arising on the revaluation of monetary items (debtors, creditors, cash, etc.)
and on derivatives to which hedge accounting has not been applied.

(6) We define MSA recharge as group management services charges which cover the transaction costs associated with previous
refinancing or capital structuring projects.

(7) The adjustment for transformational hires includes the removal of costs for hiring new teams or individual employees with
experience from industries or product lines in which the Group does not have existing operations. It includes costs associated with
buying out new hires of existing contracts, bonus schemes, sign-on deals and any net losses associated with new joiners who have
annual salaries of at least £80,000 (or the equivalent in jurisdictions outside the United Kingdom) up to the first year after any
capacity or covenant restriction.

(8) The adjustment for business transformation costs includes the removal of certain costs incurred in achieving synergies from
enhancing existing business processes, such as restructuring and investing in new systems, cost savings and process improvements.

(9) The adjustment for legacy costs includes the removal of the costs associated with resolving legacy issues within the Group that are
not related to the Group’s current trading activity and have been corrected over time. The amount of adjustments related to legacy
costs has reduced period-on-period during the periods presented.

(10) We define other costs as costs that are outside of the normal course of business, including (i) costs incurred in 2020 and 2021 that
are directly attributable to the COVID-19 pandemic that would not have been incurred otherwise, (ii) professional fee relating to a
transaction involving an equity investment into The Ardonagh Group Limited, including post-deal advice to the Group’s investors
in relation to non-cash MIPs; and (iii) non-cash MIP and share based payment charged in the Ireland P&C segment of the Global
P&C platform relating to Arachas.

(11) We define regulatory costs as costs associated with one-off regulatory reviews and with changes in the regulatory and compliance
environments.

(12) We define acquisition and financing costs as costs associated with acquiring businesses, with disposing of parts of the business,
with raising additional financing (legal and accounting advisors, rating agencies, etc.), and with a change in the value of contingent
consideration (after the measurement period has ended).

(13) Pro Forma for Completed Transactions are adjustments to give pro forma effect to (i) all acquisitions completed during the period,
and (ii) financing transactions, in each case, as if they had occurred on the first day of the period.

(14) Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Completed Transactions (including AccuRisk Disposal) are adjustments to give pro forma effect to (i) all
material acquisitions completed between October 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023, including certain cost and procurement
synergies, and (ii) the disposal of AccuRisk following its sale in the fourth quarter of 2023, in each case, as if they had occurred
on the first day of the period.

(15) Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Organic Growth adjusts for organic growth for the three months ended December 31, 2023, calculated as
the Adjusted EBITDA contribution for the three months ended December 30, 2023 less the Adjusted EBITDA contribution for the
three months ended December 31, 2022, in each case, on a constant perimeter basis as of September 30, 2023. See “—Recent
_Developments—Trading Update.”_

(16) Pro Forma for Cost savings and synergies (excluding AccuRisk) comprises acquisition synergies and operational efficiencies across
the Group. Approximately 56% of this adjustment relates to annualizing the impact of benefits not yet realized from initiatives that
have already been completed as if they had already been realized on the first day of the period. The remaining adjustment reflects
the benefits of initiatives are in process and expected to be completed within 12 months as if they had already been realized on the
first day of the period.

(17) Pro Forma for Completed Acquisitions (post-December 31, 2023) are adjustments to give pro forma effect to all material
acquisitions completed between January 1, 2024 and February 1, 2024, including certain cost and procurement synergies as if they
had occurred on the first day of the period.

(18) Pro Forma Transactions under LOI are adjustments that give pro forma effect to 36 acquisitions across Europe, Australia, Brazil,
the United Kingdom and Ireland that are contractually committed or subject to a signed letter of intent and at an advanced stage of
negotiations as of February 1, 2024, expected to complete by the end of the second quarter of 2024, including expected cost and
procurement synergies, as if they had occurred on the first day of the period.

(19) This adjustment reflects the EBITDA contribution of producer hires, who have not yet reached maturity, assuming their production
at 100% maturity, net of assumed bonuses. We estimate the expected contribution of transformational hires at maturity based on
the investment case with a 25% haircut at the time of the respective addition to the business and adjusted following regular
subsequent sensitivity assessments on a team-by-team basis based on performance and market conditions. In the twelve months

46


-----

ended September 30, 2023, we had (i) seven teams hired in 2020 at a maturity of 75%; (ii) seven teams hired in 2021 at a maturity
of 58%; (iii) seven teams hired in 2022 at a maturity of 37%; and (iv) eight teams hired in 2023 who were in the restriction period.

(20) This adjustment reflects contribution from (i) completed enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements in place to better serve
our existing customers (the costs of which have already been included in our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other
comprehensive income) and (ii) further enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements (the costs of which have already been
included in our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income) that have already been implemented but
are not yet at maturity, as if they had been fully mature during the period.
