**Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2021 Compared to**
**the Year Ended December 31, 2020**

**_Total Income_**

Total income increased by 32.5%, or £232.0 million, to £945.8 million in the year ended December 31,
2021 from £713.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due strong
organic revenue growth in our Global P&C and Specialty Broking platforms, partially offset by a small
decline in Retail resulting from market volatility towards the end of 2021.

114


-----

**_Salaries and associated costs_**

Salaries and associated costs increased by 29.3%, or £101.2 million, to £446.7 million in the year ended
December 31, 2021 from £345.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was
primarily due to an increase in the number of employees in 2021. As a percentage of Total Income,
salaries and associated costs from continuing operations decreased from 48.4% for the year ended
December 31, 2020 to 47.2% for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease of salaries and
associated costs from continuing operations was primarily due to the impact of various business
transformation programs.

**_Other operating costs_**

Other operating costs increased by 28.3%, or £58.5 million, to £264.9 million in the year ended
December 31, 2021 from £206.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was
primarily due an increase in the number of acquisitions completed in 2021. As a percentage of Total
Income, other operating costs from continuing operations decreased from 28.9% for the year ended
December 31, 2020 to 28.0% for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease was primarily due
to the impact of various business transformation programs.

**_Depreciation, amortisation and impairment of non-financial assets_**

Depreciation, amortisation and impairment of non-financial assets increased by 22.1%, or £21.3
million, to £117.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 from £96.2 million in the year ended
December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due to the increase in the number of acquisitions
completed from mid-2020 through 2021 (notably the acquisition of Bravo and the acquisition of
Arachas).

**_Finance costs_**

Finance costs decreased by 13.3%, or £31.3 million, to £204.5 million in the year ended December 31,
2021 from £235.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily due to an
amendment to the terms of the Existing Term Facilities on August 19, 2021. Pursuant to the amendment,
the margin on the Existing Term Facilities was reduced by 0.25%, and the option to pay interest in kind
was removed. On November 18, 2021, the foregoing margins were further reduced by 0.50% due to the
change to the consolidated senior net leverage ratio.

**_Tax credit/(expense)_**

Tax credit was £22.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 as compared to a tax expense of
£17.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The change was primarily due to the higher
corporate tax in 2020.

**_Loss for the period_**

Loss for the period decreased by 64.0%, or £127.5 million, to £71.9 million in the year ended December
31, 2021 from £199.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily due to
a reduction in financing costs as compared to the prior period due to certain one-off costs related to the
refinancing of our senior secured notes and revolving credit facility in 2020 and a decrease in tax
charges.

**_Adjusted EBITDA_**

Adjusted EBITDA increased by 41.6%, or £94.2 million, to £320.3 million in the year ended December
31, 2021 from £226.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due to
strong organic growth across all platforms, with the exception of Retail where growth was flat, through

115


-----

a combination of income growth in both existing and newly acquired businesses and the delivery of
significant cost savings through ongoing programs.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Liquidity describes the availability of liquid resources and ability of a company to generate sufficient
cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs,
capital expenditure, debt service obligations, other commitments, contractual obligations and
acquisitions. Proactive and careful management of our liquidity continues to be a key priority for us,
utilizing both medium (12 months rolling) and short-term (13 weeks rolling) forecasts. Our liquidity
requirements arise primarily to meet our debt service obligations, to fund capital expenditures, to fund
salaries and other associated costs and to fund acquisitions. Going forward, our primary sources of
liquidity are provided by our cash from operating activities and drawings under the Revolving Credit
Facility. In addition, we received net proceeds for issuance of share capital from our shareholders in the
amount of £134.9 million in January 2023 and £187.4 million in March 2023.

Our debt service obligations consist primarily of interest payments on the Existing Senior Secured
Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes, and following the Transactions, including the Offering, will
consist of interest payments on the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Notes.

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available
borrowings will be adequate to meet our anticipated general liquidity needs and debt service obligations,
we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations to meet these
needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us
to fund our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Notes or other debt when due. If our
cash flows from operating activities are lower than expected or our capital expenditure requirements
exceed our projections, we may be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available
on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and our cost of
capital depends on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit
from banks, other financial institutions, and capital markets, restrictions in instruments governing our
debt, and our general financial performance. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Financial Profile”
and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Financial Profile—Our substantial leverage and debt service
_obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with_
_respect to the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral.”_

**Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures About Our Market Risk**

The Group is exposed to market risk through its use of financial instruments and specifically to foreign
currency risk and interest rate risk.

**_Foreign Currency Risk_**

Our primary exposure to foreign currency risk arises from (i) our borrowings in U.S. dollars and (ii)
settlement in foreign currency, principally U.S. dollars, of brokerage and fees related to the placement
of insurance business originating outside of the United Kingdom. We use derivatives, specifically
forward contracts to mitigate this risk.

We have forward contracts that mitigate our exposure to certain U.S. dollar-denominated revenue
arising on the placement of premiums, which is not the presentation nor the functional currency of the
Group. Based on forecast transactions, we effectively sell U.S. dollar-denominated revenue by reference
to individual brokerage transactions.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Our main exposure to interest rate risk arises from our floating rate Existing Secured Credit Facilities,
and following the Transactions, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. These loans bear interest at an
applicable margin plus EURIBOR or SONIA. We use derivatives, specifically interest rate swaps, to
mitigate our interest rate risk. We expect to continue to be exposed to interest rate risk following the
Transactions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile—The New Senior Secured
_Credit Facilities will bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our interest_
_cost and reducing cash flow.”_

**Significant Accounting Policies**

Significant accounting policies are those that (i) are relevant to the presentation of our financial
condition and results of operations and (ii) require management to make judgments, estimates and
assumptions that affect the application of accounting policies and the reported amounts of assets and
liabilities, income and expenses. In order to provide an understanding of how we form our judgments,
including the variables underlying their estimates and assumptions and the sensitivity of those
judgments to different circumstances, we have identified the significant accounting polices discussed
below. While we believe that all aspects of our financial statements should be studied and understood
in assessing our current and expected financial condition and results of operations, we believe the
following significant accounting policies warrant particular attention.

**_Critical judgments in applying accounting policies_**

Certain judgments that have been made in applying accounting policies are considered to be critical.

_Acquisitions and Disposals_

AGHL obtained control of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited on June 1, 2022. For the year ended
December 31, 2022, AGHL applied acquisition accounting in accordance with IFRS 3 Business
Combinations to the acquisition of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited at fair value on June 1, 2022, which
included the recognition of intangible assets arising on a business combination and the recognition of
goodwill and non-controlling interests. A critical judgment was applied in the prior year to determine
if it was appropriate to apply acquisition accounting, which included consideration of the wider
transaction, if there had been a change of control, and who was the acquirer. Acquisition accounting
was applied as a business had been acquired and because AGHL clearly obtained control of that
business. As at December 31, 2022, we had not completed the acquisition accounting of Ardonagh New
Midco 3 Limited. Goodwill recognized in the prior year’s consolidated financial statements was based

119


-----

on provisional fair values of the assets acquired. The initial allocation of goodwill to the cash generating
units was also done on a provisional basis in accordance with IAS 36. During 2023, AGHL and its
subsidiaries completed the acquisition accounting of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, and the resulting
amount of goodwill has been finalized and reallocated to cash-generating units in a manner that is most
appropriate to the business.

During 2023, AGHL and its subsidiaries entered into negotiations to dispose of the entire share capital
of Atlanta Investment Holdings 3 Limited, being the holding company for the Retail operating segment.
On September 1, 2023, all material matters fundamental to the deal were agreed upon with the buyer
and there were no further matters that could have caused the planned sale to be withdrawn or changed
significantly. Consequently, as at that date the disposal group was classified as held for sale in
accordance with IFRS 5 Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations. At that date,
the carrying values of all assets and liabilities within the disposal group were measured in accordance
with applicable IFRS and then compared to the fair value less cost to sell of the disposal group. The
excess, if any, of the carrying value of the disposal group over its fair value less cost to sell is required
to be recognized as an impairment loss. There was no material difference between the carrying value
and the fair value less cost to sell of the disposal group and therefore no impairment loss was recognized.
Furthermore, in accordance with IFRS 5, from the date of classification as held for sale, non-current
assets within the disposal group are not subject to depreciation or amortisation.

**_Key sources of estimation uncertainty_**

_Impairment of assets_

We test annually whether goodwill and intangible assets that have indefinite useful lives have suffered
any impairment. Other assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances
indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may exceed their recoverable amounts. The last annual
impairment test was performed as of July 1, 2023.

An impairment test of an asset or cash-generating unit (or group of cash-generating units) is performed
by comparing its carrying amount with its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher
of its fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use, where its value in use is the present value of
its future cash flows. An impairment test requires the application of significant judgment because it
relies on key assumptions, including forecast cash flows, a discount rate, a terminal growth rate and an
Adjusted EBITDA multiple. Accordingly, the resulting estimates are significant estimates because there
is a significant risk of a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of affected balances within the
next financial year.

Goodwill arising from a new business combination is, for the purposes of impairment testing, allocated
to those cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from the goodwill that was acquired.
Impairment testing is performed at the level of the smallest groups of cash-generating units at which
goodwill is monitored, known as the divisions. Forecast cash flows used in the value in use calculation
were determined by considering historic business performance, by overlaying it with assumptions to
reflect areas where growth or income improvement was expected, and by taking into account the
expected results of cost management programs to which we are committed. The forecasts were
extrapolated to subsequent years using a steady growth rate being the forecast CPI inflation rate of 2%,
and a terminal value was calculated using the perpetual growth model. The discount rate of 9.55% to
11.45% that was applied to the forecasts was a market participant weighted average cost of capital
calculated by reference to the Capital Asset Pricing Model.

The fair value of AGHL and its subsidiaries was calculated based on multiples of forecast 2024
Adjusted EBITDA and on information provided by external advisors, where that information is based
on recent transactions in the insurance broking industry. The fair value of an operating segment was
estimated by apportioning the fair value of our group between the operating segments based on the

120


-----

value in use of each operating segment. The estimated costs of disposal are assumed, based on market
experience, to be 1.5% of the fair value of the operating segment. As of September 30, 2023, there were
no indications of impairment and therefore no impairment test has been performed.

**INDUSTRY OVERVIEW**

**Overview**

Providing insurance coverage to customers entails a series of activities, including (i) providing risk
capital, a service exclusively provided by insurance and reinsurance companies; (ii) underwriting
insurance policies, a service that requires in-depth technical knowledge; and (iii) distribution, a service
that requires knowledge of the customer base and of the risks to the customer. The amount of financial
risk an insurance or a reinsurance company is willing to assume in relation to its insurance policies is a
function of underwriting appetite and capital or capacity. The participants in the intermediation of
insurance products are principally brokers, underwriting agencies and aggregators as well as insurers
selling directly to customers. The chart below shows the participants across the insurance distribution
chain.

**Insurance products**

Insurance products, both specialist and non-specialist, can be broadly classified into three types: (A)
General non-life personal lines insurance; (B) General non-life commercial lines insurance, which
includes SME commercial lines insurance; and (C) Life, pensions and other financial services
insurance.

**_General non-life personal lines insurance_**

General non-life personal lines insurance is sold to individual customers and includes accident and
sickness coverage, household insurance, motor insurance, along with travel and personal accident
insurance. In these segments, specialist non-life personal lines insurance products are sold to individual
customers in niche areas within a segment or those with non-standard risk profiles, such as classic car
insurance or insurance for learner drivers.

**_General non-life commercial lines insurance_**

General non-life commercial lines insurance is sold to commercial customers and includes construction
insurance, commercial property insurance, commercial combined insurance, office and contents
insurance, professional indemnity insurance, fleet insurance, employer liability insurance, agriculture

122


-----

insurance, marine insurance and transport insurance. SME commercial lines insurance is sold to SMEs.
Specialist non-life commercial lines insurance is also sold to commercial customers in niche markets.

**_Life, pensions and other financial services insurance_**

Life, pensions and other financial services insurance is sold to individual customers and includes life
insurance, pensions, annuities and investment products.

**Insurance supply chain**

There are broadly three main activities in the insurance supply chain:

**_Providing risk capital_**

Risk taking activity in the insurance supply chain is undertaken by insurance companies who underwrite
insurance and expose their balance sheets to loss. Insurance companies earn income (i) from premiums;
and (ii) by investing their available reserves, that is, the amount of money at any given time collected
in premium but not yet paid out in claims.

Traditionally, insurance companies sold indirectly through intermediaries such as brokers and
underwriting agencies but in certain markets and product areas they now also sell insurance directly,
via telephone or online. Traditionally, insurance companies also performed all the services necessary
for providing insurance, including underwriting, administering insurance policies and handling
insurance claims and renewals. Today, many insurance companies outsource these services to
intermediaries.

**_Distribution_**

The distribution of insurance products is carried out by brokers, underwriting agencies and through
PCWs. In certain markets and product areas, insurers also distribute products directly to customers.

_Brokers_

Broking is the process by which a broker negotiates insurance policy terms for a customer and places
that customer’s risk with an appropriate insurance company either directly or through an underwriting
agency. Customers include businesses, individuals and public institutions, and, in the case of wholesale
brokers, other brokers. Brokers connect insurance companies and underwriting agencies with customers
in the insurance supply chain and so act as a distribution channel for insurance products. Insurance
companies and underwriting agencies, as the case may be, compensate brokers by means of
commissions based on premium levels and fees for individual services. In certain cases, brokers will
forego some or all of the commission payable by the insurance company and instead be compensated
by the customer for the placement service (particularly in personal lines).

_Underwriting agencies_

An underwriting agent serves as an intermediary between an insurance company and a broker or the
customer. In addition to providing underwriting services, some underwriting agencies act as MGA by
issuing and administering insurance policies and handling insurance claims and renewals on behalf of
insurance companies. Such underwriting agencies operate as “virtual insurers”, performing most
functions of a traditional insurance company including underwriting and pricing, but excluding the
provision of capital and the incurrence of liability in respect of insurance claims. The performance of
an underwriting agency can be judged by its underwriting results, the amount of total premiums earned
minus the cost of claims and operating expenses. Notably, there may be “loss-sharing” arrangements
put in place between the insurance company and the underwriting agency that can impact profitability,
depending on underwriting performance.

123


-----

_Price Comparison Websites (PCWs)_

PCWs are internet portals that allow insurance companies and insurance intermediaries to make their
insurance products available directly to customers via the internet. Customers can obtain several quotes
from insurance companies and insurance intermediaries on aggregator websites by making only one
data entry. The insurance company or insurance intermediary with the most appealing (by terms or
price) quote issues the insurance policy to the customer and compensates the PCW by means of a
referral fee.

PCWs are predominantly used to sell personal motor insurance policies and, to a lesser extent,
household insurance policies as well as other personal lines products. PCWs have had a limited impact
on the sale of commercial lines (except commercial auto) of insurance due to the complexity of the
products and the “off-line” advice sought by commercial customers for most commercial insurance
products.

In many cases, the PCW is reliant on another insurance intermediary, such as a broker or an
underwriting agency, to fulfill a number of critical activities such as managing the panel of insurers
whose products are available on the website. Similarly, an insurer may contract with a broker to manage
the insurer’s presence on a number of PCWs.

**_Service providers_**

_Network service providers_

Network service providers offer independent brokers access to insurance products that are not typically
available to independent brokers as well as enhanced agency terms, in effect operating as a buying club.
Network service providers also offer independent brokers access to certain business support services
such as handling of client money, risk & compliance and marketing.

_Service companies_

As insurers, MGAs, brokers and other participants in the insurance market look to improve cost
efficiencies in fulfillment, specialists offering business process outsourcing have become more
significant in the market. The initial focus of these service providers have been on claims fulfillment,
including completion of the first notification of loss, claims validation, litigation services, and other
associated claims services. These service providers have also branched out into other areas such as
customer services, sales campaign management, premium finance and white-labelled products.

**Insurance market structure and size**

_UK non-life insurance market_

The UK non-life insurance market grew by 6.7% in 2022 to £71.1 billion and is forecasted to grow to
£80.2 billion by 2027 according to Fitch Solutions.

The global non-life insurance market grew at a CAGR of 5.7% from 2000 to 2022 and is valued at $4
trillion. The map below presents the global insurance market on the basis of real non-life premium.

_International London market_

The international London market (the “London Market”) is the largest global center for commercial
and specialty risk with an emphasis on high-exposure, complex risk. Key types of risk insured in the
London Market include marine, aviation, catastrophe, professional indemnity and product liability. The
London Market controlled more than $121 billion of gross written premium in 2020 consisting of $84
billion written directly by London and $37 billion marketed and controlled through London according
to London Market Group.

**_Industry dynamics and trends_**

_Competitive landscape_

The competition for business has been one of the primary factors that has been driving broker
consolidation by non-vertically integrated players in the highly competitive UK market in recent years.
Consolidation is driven by the need to gain scale to effectively compete with larger, vertically integrated
players, particularly in the personal lines market. A variety of other factors have also driven these
acquisitions, including the increase in compliance and administrative costs resulting from new FCA
regulations, the aging broker demographic, recognition of the potential for economies of scale and the
consequent enhanced ability to compete effectively on price to drive increases in win-rates. The group
has a proven track record of M&A across all of its platforms, and believes there remain significant
opportunities to acquire brokers of varying sizes, which can add capabilities and customer volumes.

_UK Insurance distribution trends_

Brokers are the primary distribution channel in the UK non-life market.

Client purchasing behavior differs between customer types. Accordingly, brokers account for differing
percentages of GWP depending on the type of insurance being transacted with a large majority of
commercial premium transacted by brokers compared with a smaller amount of personal lines premium.

125


-----

Brokers will likely remain the largest SME market distribution channel due to the complexity of covers
required and development of digital capabilities.

With the expansion of the internet, the amount of personal insurance products sold by means of PCWs
has grown significantly. Expansion is expected to continue at a more modest rate as customers continue
to use PCWs. PCWs will likely continue to dominate the standard personal insurance markets, but will
increasingly look to other markets both geographically and from a product perspective. PCWs have
previously tried to sell other insurance products directly; however, they experience greater success when
partnering with existing product specialists. PCWs allow existing product specialists to make their
insurance products available directly to customers via the internet, and as such, PCWs are not direct
competitors of existing product specialists, but rather serve as intermediaries between them and end
customers.

_New emerging risks_

The broker’s role in connection with non-standard risks is becoming increasingly important. The market
is experiencing an increased appetite for newer risk categories, including cyber, supply chain and
legislative, and as more customers look to insure against these new risks, the role of advice and
significance of choice will become more important and the use of on brokers will subsequently increase.
This is in particular relevant to any complex, large or otherwise sophisticated risks, which demand a
broker-advised sale as opposed to a low involvement sale through PCWs.

_Increase in divestment / redistribution of unprofitable products or processes_

As all participants in the insurance market seek to improve profit margins, there is an increasing trend
for organizations to divest and outsource unprofitable products or processes to specialists who charge
an administrative fee or take a cut of commission. More of the larger insurers and other insurance
intermediaries, such as banks and retailers, are actively using white-labelled products from other
insurance providers. MGAs, brokers and other participants in the insurance market have also benefitted
from the use and distribution of white-labelled products.

_Increasing reliance on technology_

Technology is playing an increasingly important role in all aspects of the insurance market. Significant
investments are required by insurers and their distributors in order to ensure that customer service levels
remain high, fraud is controlled, product design is fit-for-purpose and underwriting risk is managed.
The use and analysis of data is critical to a successful insurance distribution chain.

opportunities is on the customer proposition and financial returns. We have also implemented a robust
and efficient integration and post-deal tracking process after closing.

134

Our disciplined execution focuses on a clear, orderly and highly selective strategy based on ten
principles: strategic fit, cultural fit, integration commitment, aligned incentives, financial returns,
synergy discipline, cash discipline, realistic plan, risk assessment and clear accountability. We perform
a rigorous due diligence process through a highly experienced and dedicated team of investment
professionals, leveraging deep local knowledge in the markets where we operate and a robust and
efficient integration and post-deal tracking process. We are able to present ourselves as the acquirer of
choice by emphasizing our culture, aligning interests and maintaining discipline. In addition, we have
made significant investments in our technology platform, which allows us to integrate new acquisitions
at low cost and with low integration risk.

**_Leading data and analytics capabilities driving platform efficiencies_**

Our leading centralized data and analytics capabilities allow us to enhance risk solutions for capacity
providers and improve outcomes for our clients and to drive cost savings. These capabilities have been
primarily utilized to support the building of broker facilities, which then allow us to access
predominantly traditional capacity in more efficient ways for the client. For example, we have used data
and analytics to significantly improve and re-package older previous products into better terms, cover
and product for our clients, including improvements on the Terrorism, Fine Art Jewellery and Specie
facilities. We have also used data and analytics to introduce brand new facilities to the market, such as
a Construction facility and a cross-class facility named LECTIO. The following chart shows our
centralized data analytics structure, where we have centralized global premium and carrier information
using our data center based in Mullingar, Ireland.

As an example, in our Specialty Broking platform, we have built facilities such as the Ardonagh
Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business to use data analytics and capabilities to bring benefits to both
clients, in terms of wider market placement, and our Group, in terms of increased revenues.

Our technology and scale facilities have also allowed us to identify cost savings totalling approximately
£15.8 million that we expect to achieve within the next 12 months. In our Global P&C: UK Advisory
segment, we expect cost savings of £3.2 million, primarily as a result of a target model implementation
project that has reduced headcount through efficiency gains from optimizing policy administration
systems, an IT transformation from improving the office network, which is aimed at removing legacy
applications and outsourcing, and an onshoring finance project expected to deliver benefits from process
efficiencies and automation. In our Global P&C: International Advisory segment, we expect cost
savings of £3.9 million from synergies through our hub-and-spoke model and by integrating further

**_Attractive financial profile with strong growth, profitability and cash flow conversion_**

Since our establishment in 2017, we have delivered a transformational improvement in our quality of

to Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA (excluding Retail) during the same period. We also experienced
a more than eight percentage points increase in organic growth from 2017 to the twelve months ended
September 30, 2023 (excluding Retail) and a more than 13 percentage point increase in Adjusted
EBITDA margin over the same time period (excluding Retail).

We have designed our business model to generate high EBITDA margins with limited working capital
and maintenance capital expenditure requirements, resulting in management operating cash flow of
£420 million and an operating cash conversion of 86% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023.
Since our establishment, we have delivered a transformational improvement in quality of earnings,
primarily as a result of significant investments towards transformative cost-savings programs and
synergy initiatives in our business to create a scalable and efficient platform that is conducive to future
growth, resulting in approximately £150 million of realized cost-savings since the start of 2018. Our
investments have resulted in a continued and rapid improvement in our quality of earnings as cost
savings are delivered and one-time costs have decreased. We believe that our cash generative business
model is highly scalable and that we will be able to leverage our well-invested infrastructure as we
continue to grow organically and via acquisitions.

**_Deep, aligned management team well positioned to drive culture and lead ongoing growth_**

Our management team is highly experienced in leading and growing successful insurance intermediary
organizations. Our Chief Executive Officer, David Ross, has over 25 years of industry experience
building and leading brokerage businesses including leading transformative mergers and acquisitions
in the insurance intermediary field. Mr. Ross is supported by a highly experienced management team
with over 25 years of industry experience on average, with a strong track record of delivering on
transformative change and investment. Our Chief Financial Officer, Diane Cougill, has over 20 years
of industry experience and has held senior leadership positions at RAC and at Aviva. Our senior
management team also includes Aurelio Cusaro, our Chief Investment Officer, John Tiner, our
Chairman, Geoff Gouriet, our General Counsel, and Sarah Dalgarno, our Chief Risk Officer. Our Global
P&C senior management includes Rob Worrell, Chief Executive Officer of our UK Advisory segment,
Conor Brennan, Chairman of our International Advisory segment and Des O’Connor, Chief Investment
Officer of our International Advisory segment. Our Specialty Broking senior management includes
Chief Executive Officer Andrew Wallin and Chairman James Masterson. Together, this team leads a
deep bench of revenue-producing talent and committed operational support staff, all of whom have been
specifically targeted for their entrepreneurial spirit and ability to drive sustainable revenue growth. The
culture cultivated by our senior management team leads to our continued success in the insurance
market and differentiates itself from other competitors in various ways, including:

  - An emphasis on entrepreneurship at a local level with strong organizational alignment, resulting
in colleagues working together towards common, Group-wide objectives,

  - Continuous cross-group collaboration to amplify the best of our collective experience and
insight,

  - The application of the depth and breadth of our specialist expertise, built through years of
market leadership,

  - Our tailored and innovative solutions and ability to understand what works for each industry,
market and client,

  - Our deep relationships with clients built through longstanding service, accountability and trust,
and

  - Our regular programming to celebrate special accomplishments and promote internal events.

These factors have resulted in over 90% client retention based on strong relationships, knowledge and

a broader platform, our emphasis on training, development and support, our aligned incentives with
producers and our collaborative and cohesive culture.

**Strategies**

**_Accelerate organic growth by optimizing placement strategy and driving new business through new_**
**_products, cross-selling and up-selling_**

We seek to consistently achieve double-digit organic growth across our overall business by expanding
product portfolios, streamlining operations, increasing penetration of our customer base—particularly
in new synergistic geographies—through concerted sales efforts across our Group and capitalizing on
a targeted acquisitions pipeline. We have a growing pipeline of new specialist products that is highly
complementary to our existing offerings, including high net worth, political violence, specialty
terrorism facility. These products are being developed on existing systems and channels at limited
upfront cost and are largely linked to new hires, who can contribute the relevant product and channel
expertise. As an example, new products launched in our Specialty Broking platform contributed towards
organic growth of approximately 11.6% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023.

As part of our organic growth strategy, we are also focused on cross-selling and up-selling and customer
retention and expansion. We seek to improve cross-selling and up-selling across Group clients,
including by leveraging data. We have rolled out of a Group-wide database in which we collate data
from each of our platforms to enable a “single view of the client” (i.e., how many policies are linked to
each client across personal and commercial lines) to facilitate retention, cross-selling and up-selling.
This database continues to provide a more granular understanding of our clients’ needs, allowing us to
offer them tailored cross-selling opportunities. We have also implemented a bespoke pricing system
and leveraged our data infrastructure, fraud detection capabilities and access to third-party data sources
to improve retention and increase customer lifetime value across most products. In our Specialty
Broking platform, we have developed a highly sophisticated customer and broker-facing software
which interfaces with several market-leading policy administrative systems and substantially improves
ease of access to customer and broker data. We are also in discussions with several third-party brokers
who are clients of our wholesale platform to roll-out this software in order to maximize efficiency and
centralization within our platform and improve the experience of third-party brokers on our platform.
We also intend to leverage our membership of the Worldwide Broker Network to increase existing
business and in-flow through the establishment of new relationships and intend to capitalize on our
existing global footprint to drive further growth. In the UK, our UK Advisory business launched a
focused client strategy aimed at large UK corporates, which is already bearing fruit with the successful
signing of several marquee clients, including a global broadcaster that has a £5 billion turnover and also
the UK’s largest charity.

In addition, in 2021, we launched Inver Re, a new risk strategy and reinsurance broker with ambitions
to harness our scale, resources and reach to offer a credible alternative to global brokers and become
our industry’s independent reinsurance broker of choice. We plan to further strengthen our reinsurance
operations by (i) consolidating our existing reinsurance operations while organically building out our
brand, talent and capabilities in key global hubs (such as London, North America & Bermuda), (ii)
developing our first party business through leveraging key group carrier relationships, (iii) hiring
industry leading talent and building further revenue streams and (iv) deploying M&A to expand
geographic focus beyond key hubs (such as in Latin America and Asia).

138


-----

**_Streamline operations through our continued focus on capacity excellence, talent excellence and_**
**_operational excellence_**

We are constantly re-examining our operating models to incrementally streamline lower value-add
operations and further support our front-office distribution and client service capabilities. We have
developed a range of strategies to streamline operations and optimize middle and back-office functions.
Our strategy is based on three key pillars of excellence, which are:

- _Capacity excellence. We seek to reach capacity excellence by operating a strategic capacity_
model through our Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business, part of our Specialty
Broking platform. APS utilizes data captured from across the Group’s platforms and businesses
to enhance income through a centralized placement. We expect our APS business to be a key
growth driver going forward by allowing us to capitalize on a select number of strategic carrier
relationships, create market leading products which offer better terms for our customers and
access alternative capital providers either directly or in connection with our MGA business. We
intend to engage with APS for select high-profitability lines and actively manage the portfolio
to reduce exposure to underperforming lines.

- _Talent excellence. We believe that we will be able to deliver significant incremental income_
and EBITDA growth by nurturing talent excellence. We are working to attract the best people
in our industry and are ideally placed to capitalize on market dislocation. We believe that
incoming hires bring capabilities and are highly accretive. We have a strong track record of
income hires and producer recruitment, delivering significant incremental income and
EBITDA. We intend to leverage our success to date to continue selective transformational hires,
focusing on hiring exceptional individuals who can swiftly add value to our Group. Since 2019,
we have secured at least five new specialist team hires per year, and currently have a deep
pipeline of future hires. We also intend to deliver on exceptional existing hires, relentlessly
focusing on renewal retention, leveraging existing retail and wholesale relationships.

- _Operational excellence. We believe that through operational excellence we can continue our_
track record of delivering value through our focus on operational expertise. We have delivered
cost efficiencies to drive margin expansion across all divisions, resulting in approximately £150
million of synergies and cost savings delivered to date since the start of 2018, and £15.8 million
of cost savings and cost synergies expected to be delivered within the next twelve months,
consisting of (i) £3.2 million within the UK Advisory platform resulting from benefits from a
target operating model implementation project that has reduced headcount through efficiency
gains from optimizing policy administration systems, IT transformations from improving the
office network, removing legacy applications and outsourcing and an onshoring finance project
expected to deliver benefits from process efficiencies and automation, (ii) £8.2 million within
the Specialty Broking platform resulting from the technology-led transformation of our middle
and back office functions and the cost synergies identified with the acquisition of Corant
Global, including the harmonization of reward structures, footprint consolidation and backoffice optimization, as well as the acquisition of Oxford Insurance, (iii) £3.9 million within the
International Advisory platform through the ‘hub and spoke’ model and the integration of
further acquisitions into existing platforms and (iv) £0.5 million through back-office
optimization in our Corporate segment.

We also continue to make significant investments into our technology platform, as we believe that
digital solutions will get us closer to our end client, allowing us to leverage and overlay external tools
to attract new business and protect existing business.

**_Expand our addressable markets in new synergistic geographies_**

We intend to continue expanding our addressable markets in synergistic geographies. In 2021 we
established our International Advisory platform, under which we are consolidating our non-UK broking

139


-----

enterprises and related investments and under which we have launched our Ardonagh Europe and our
Ardonagh Global Partners businesses. We established Ardonagh Global Partners in 2021 to invest in
leading platforms operating in attractive markets and verticals outside the UK and Europe and to partner
with management teams who want to grow faster as part of a larger group while retaining operational
independence. We intend to continue growing our International Advisory platform with the aim of
consolidating our presence in a selected portfolio of fast-growing markets and expanding participation
in select new products and markets where there is significant synergy between our UK platforms and
our International Advisory platform. We are focusing on a number of regions which fulfil our
acquisition criteria, and intend to employ the hub and spoke methodology to quickly expand our
regional presence. Our aim is to develop a number of regional hubs, with specialist knowledge,
technology and product expertise, to support in-country assets, and we intend to focus on strategic
markets with assets that are capable of executing further in-country expansion.

**_Continue to grow by capitalizing on targeted acquisitions pipeline_**

As part of our strategy, we target additional growth expected from accretive acquisitions, and intend to
further strengthen our position and broaden our portfolio by continuing to consolidate smaller players
in the highly fragmented and competitive UK and international insurance markets. Any acquisition we
pursue will be in line with our targeted and selective acquisition criteria focused on companies with
attractive profitability, growth potential and complementary business operations. We utilize our
network to identify suitable targets at reasonable multiples. We support acquired assets post-acquisition
in order to achieve our organic growth plans going forward, utilizing our expertise and networks. We
also manage the realization of identified revenue and cost synergies on an ongoing basis. We have a
highly disciplined and proven acquisition program, which includes a standardized approach to
integration and synergy delivery, which, together with the proven execution ability of our management
team and our strong focus on value creation and financial metrics, allows us to maximize synergies and
rapidly deploy economies of scale to acquired businesses.

We have a robust M&A pipeline underpinned by a rigorous evaluation and assessment process driven
by an experienced and dedicated team of M&A professionals, and we continue to explore larger
transaction opportunities both in the UK and internationally with a strong focus on market-leading
platforms in our international business. Acquisitions completed during the fourth quarter of 2023
(including the impact of the AccuRisk disposal) contributed Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £13.6
million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, and acquisitions completed between January
1, 2024 and February 1, 2024 contributed an additional £3.0 million. We have a further 36 acquisitions
that are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent as of February 1, 2024, which would
contribute an additional £32.2 million of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Our pipeline includes targets
on multiple continents. We are also actively pursuing other acquisitions in the near-term or very nearterm, including one or more potentially material acquisitions.

**History**

We were established in 2017 through the combination of several insurance services providers into a
single multi-product and multi-channel platform led by a highly experienced senior management team
with the aim of fostering innovation in the insurance market. Since our establishment, we have
continued to grow through a combination of a sustained focus on organic growth, operational excellence
and a highly disciplined expense strategy, and acquisition program, which includes a standardized
approach to integration and synergy delivery, and which we believe allows us to maximize synergies
and rapidly deploy economies of scale to acquired businesses.

Our business strategy has followed a three phased strategy. During our first phase, from founding in
2017 until 2019, our focus was primarily on establishing scale and making our UK businesses key
competitors in their segments, specifically our Retail business containing our UK personal lines
business and our Specialty Broking business containing our London markets wholesale business, and

140


-----

adding niche and specialist lines to our commercial and SME business to create the UK Advisory
business. Our strategy was to integrate acquisitions and streamline the operations through centralized,
in-country IT and data, carrier placements and back office functions. During our second phase, between
2019 and 2022, we shifted our focus to broader international expansion, acquiring businesses with the
aim to diversify and expand our footprint while continuing to focus on operational excellence, with the
aim of improving margins in our UK markets. With the integration of acquisitions and our disciplined
approach to operational excellence, we have delivered approximately £150 million of synergies and
cost savings since the start of 2018. In the third phase of our strategy, beginning in 2023, our focus has
been to release capital unlocked by the Retail Transaction to invest in our higher organic growth Global
P&C and Specialty Broking platforms, predominantly in international markets. See “—Retail—Retail
_Transaction” below. The chart below shows the evolution of our main segments over the past three_
years.

Since 2017, we have completed more than 150 acquisitions, and in 2023 alone we completed 67
acquisitions. Our major acquisitions since mid-2020 include, among others:

- Arachas, a commercial insurance broker in Ireland, in 2020;

- Bravo, which comprises Broker Network and Compass, two established network service
providers to regional insurance brokers and Ethos Broking, a highly active acquisition platform
focused on the UK regional insurance market, in 2020;

- Resilium Pty Limited, the founding business of our Australian platform, in February 2021;

- Hemsley Wynne Furlong LLP, a specialist M&A warranty and indemnity insurance broker and
advisor, in March 2021;

- Usay Group Limited, one of the largest consumer personal medical insurance and protection
insurance brokers in the UK, in September 2021;

- the Hooper Dolan companies, a client-focused general insurance broker with offices across
Ireland, in October 2021;

- the insurance operations of BGC Partners Inc., a leading global brokerage and financial
technology company, in November 2021;

- the Léons Group, a family-owned independent insurance brokerage and consultancy firm based
in the Netherlands, in October 2022;

- Glennon Insurances, a leading provider of insurance solutions in Ireland, in December 2022;

- the Oxford Insurance Group, a Lloyd’s broker with further operations in Switzerland,

**Our Business**

Following the announcement of the Retail Transaction, our business has been organized into two main
reporting segments, which we refer to as platforms, that focus on distinct but complementary aspects of
the insurance brokerage and services value chain. Global P&C (which is comprised of UK Advisory
and International Advisory) and Specialty Broking.

We also currently own a Retail segment, which houses several digitally focused personal lines brands
which offer home, motor and pet insurance alongside a range of specialist personal and small business

142


-----

insurance products. In September 2023, we announced the Retail Transaction, following which Retail
will no longer be part of the Group. See “—Retail—Retail Transaction” below.

In addition, we maintain a non-operating Corporate segment comprising central costs and income
(primarily interest income) not allocated to our reporting segments.

**_Global P&C_**

The Global P&C platform, comprised of the UK Advisory and International Advisory platforms, is a
global broking platform mainly focused on SME and mid-corporate clients with strong market positions
across key geographies. The platform has a global network of more than 100 locations, which provides
for deeply embedded local and “trusted advisor” status with clients. Global P&C offers a broad product
set and maintains a highly active M&A strategy with a significant global pipeline of accretive bolt-ons.

_UK Advisory_

The UK Advisory platform provides a broad range of insurance broking products and advice on
insurance, risk management and employee benefits to SMEs, large corporations and individual
customers.

For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, UK Advisory generated £512.6 million of Total Pro
Forma Income and £162.6 million of Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA.

As part of UK Advisory, we offer tailored insurance broking services to our clients via in-person,
telephony, and online communications, providing them with a broad range of choices and access to
specialist products and solutions designed to meet individual needs across the full spectrum of
commercial, corporate and personal classes. The primary lines of coverage in our UK Advisory platform
include motor fleet, commercial, property, liability, professional indemnity, and contractors. We also
provide standard non-specialist insurance products tailored to specific sectors or risks that may be more
difficult to place elsewhere in the insurance market. UK Advisory maintains a strong community focus
through our network of over 120 offices across the United Kingdom. SME insurance intermediary
products require industry and customer expertise to develop and market effectively, and we believe that
SME customers value direct relationship management and advisory services when purchasing such
specialized products, which we are able to provide via our local office network.

UK Advisory operates through seven community-focused brands:

- Towergate Insurance Brokers: one of the UK’s leading independent insurance brokers and risk
management advisors providing commercial and specialist lines insurance to clients all over
the UK;

- Towergate Health & Protect: health, protection and employee benefits;

- Riskline: specialist, micro-SME focused proposition;

- Footman James: specialist classic car brand with a high-net-worth client base;

- Usay: consumer private medical insurance (“PMI”) and protection;

- Ethos Broking: regional niche and specialist broking; and

- Bravo Network: contains two of the largest networks of independent regional brokers in the
UK – Broker Network and Compass – providing insurance broking to SME businesses in the
UK.

143


-----

Towergate Insurance Brokers and Towergate Health and Protection products are sold mainly through
face-to-face relationships via the Towergate brand. Riskline is a center of excellence selling to microSMEs over the phone and online. Footman James is an established brand in the classic car insurance
sector (within the wider private motor insurance market) selling directly to consumers and, as such,
aligns to our broader high-net-worth proposition across our UK Advisory platform as a whole. Ethos
Broking and Bravo Networks provide insurance broking and member services with an SME focus via
community broking offices and a network presence. Additionally, Towergate Insurance Brokers is a
member of the Worldwide Broker Network, and can as such collaborate with other independent brokers
worldwide to deliver cross-border insurance programs.

UK Advisory is an established M&A powerhouse with a track record of successfully implementing its
acquisition strategy. Since June 2020, UK Advisory has completed 28 acquisitions, including: Bravo,
Guy Penn, Sennet, Headley, AFL Retail, Chambers & Newman, Hera, Drayton Insurance, Murton
Alexander, Thompson & Bryan, Schofields, USAY, Lorega, Stallard Kane Group, The Professional

potential, accretive bolt-on acquisitions, including through our hub-and-spoke consolidation platform,
Ethos, and Bravo Network, which comprises Broker Network and Compass, two established network
service providers to regional insurance brokers with approximately 615 members that provide a pool to
identify and execute accretive acquisitions.

_International Advisory_

The International Advisory platform consists of our non-UK broking enterprises. International Advisory
focuses on leveraging our existing scale, assets and wholesale market access to increase overall value.
We aim to develop regional hubs through hub-and-spoke methodology to build in-country assets and
support their rapid expansion through shared resources and expertise. For the twelve months ended
September 30, 2023, International Advisory generated £516.5 million of Total Pro Forma Income and
£201.1 million of Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA.

Our largest business in our International Advisory platform is based in Ireland and trades under our
Arachas brand. Arachas, an Irish SME-focused commercial insurance broker with specialized offerings
and a nationwide reach, has quickly gained a leading position in its core markets. Arachas has grown
rapidly through a combination of strong organic growth and targeted acquisition of synergistic
businesses, including O’Driscoll O’Neil DAC in 2020, Hooper Dolan and BJP Insurance Brokers in
2021 and Glennon Insurances in 2022. Other continental European businesses include Klap, Leon and
Classicus in the Netherlands and ASSEPRO, acquired in late 2023, which trades in Austria and
Switzerland.

In 2021, we focused on investing in markets and verticals outside the UK and Europe and partnering
with management teams who want to grow faster as part of a larger group while retaining operational
independence. This included our acquisition of Resilium, a large, independently owned intermediary
network in Australia and Ethos Broking Australia, which invests in or directly acquires brokers. In
December 2022, we acquired the MDS Group, an insurance broker and risk management advisor across
the Portuguese-speaking world and Europe, the only Portuguese Lloyd’s Broker and the largest
independent broker in Brazil, and in February 2023 we acquired Envest, an Australian-based insurance
investment and distribution group, which now houses Australian assets Resilium and Epsilon
Underwriting within the Group.

**_Specialty Broking_**

The Specialty Broking platform combines expertise in specialist underwriting with the placing of
bespoke complex risk products for large UK and international corporate clients. Specialty Broking
operates through globally recognized heritage brands, including Price Forbes, Bishopsgate, Ed Broking,

144


-----

Inver Re, Piiq Risk Partners, and Robus. Specialty Broking is London headquartered and in close
proximity to Lloyd’s of London and the London market, sourcing business from over 180 countries
worldwide. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, Specialty Broking generated £535.1
million of Total Pro Forma Income and £193.4 million of Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA.

Through our Lloyd’s of London brokerage business, which is one of the largest independent wholesale
broker in the London market with offices around the globe, we provide UK and international corporate
clients with open market programs, reinsurance and international solutions designed to empower clients
to achieve their strategic ambitions. Price Forbes, one of the world’s oldest specialty insurance brands,
and Bishopsgate provide UK and international corporate clients with access to specialist sector
insurance products covering a wide range of markets, including energy, North American property,
marine, power, aviation, specie (covering high-value, portable items such as gemstones and bullion),
cargo, mining and terrorism. Since June 2020, we completed the acquisitions of Robus and Rural
Insurance, and in 2021, we acquired the insurance operations of BGC Partners Inc., a leading global
brokerage and financial technology company. Most recently, in 2023, we acquired Lloyd’s broker
Oxford Insurance Group, which operates across several specialist sectors including professional
indemnity, property, general liability, marine and energy, strengthening the growth potential of our
Specialty Broking platform.

The Specialty Broking platform also includes our Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business,
which leverages the scale of the Group and optimizes our product development and capacity placement
strategy. APS is built on data captured from across Group’s platforms and businesses, creating
connectivity between segments and developing a “single view” of clients. APS centrally co-ordinates
the most appropriate placement of premiums to drive better solutions for our clients and capital
providers, enabling us to further monetize our scale. This includes the development of a number of
market-leading facilities across the terrorism and professional indemnity classes. These facilities
improve terms, pricing and quality of service to customers, consolidate multiple markets and carriers
and utilize the size, scale and diversification of a portfolio of risks.

**_Retail_**

The Retail platform operates as a digitally focused broker with price comparison websites (“PCW”)
and direct channels, offering a range of specialized home, car, and specialist products such as bike
(including products focused on particular customer categories or risk types within these segments such
as caravan or van insurance) insurance products to individuals and small businesses via a portfolio of
leading brands and leveraging on our back-office scale. Retail utilizes a data-led distribution strategy
focused on online channels, including PCW, complemented by traditional call center support, as well
as through third party intermediaries consisting of mainly independent financial advisors and mortgage
brokers. As part of the Retail platform we operate several retail-facing insurance brands, including
Autonet Insurance Group, Carole Nash, Paymentshield, Marmalade, Swinton Group, Lloyd Latchford
Group, Healthy Pets and Be Wiser Insurance.

In September 2023, we announced the merger and disposal of the Retail platform with the Markerstudy
Group, with our shareholders maintaining a stake in the combined business. The transaction values
Atlanta at £1.2 billion. The Retail Transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory
approvals. As a result of this merger and the resulting disposal of the Retail platform, in our Unaudited
Interim Financial Statements we have presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of
financial position as of September 30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated
statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September
30, 2023 and the period ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Retail
_Transaction.”_

**_Corporate_**

We maintain a non-operating segment comprising central costs and income not allocated to our
reporting segments. These costs include Group board costs and Group function costs, including certain
legal and regulatory expenses. Income in this non-operating segment primarily relates to interest
income. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, Corporate generated £28.8 million of Total
Pro Forma Income and £1.8 million of Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA.

**Information Technology**

We make significant investments into our technology platform to make it scalable and resilient. We
have retained specialist IT services provider Mphasis to deliver tailored infrastructure services across
various parts of The Ardonagh Group and are in the process of transitioning to cloud-based data centers
and a cloud-based core finance platform, which we believe will contribute to ongoing operating
efficiencies across our businesses. We also utilize Microsoft’s Azure cloud platform across several
applications. Our business benefits from what we believe to be a market leading and scalable technology
platform that can be leveraged across The Ardonagh Group, allowing us to process data more securely,
with lower error rates and at lower cost. Investments into our technology platform have also made it
easier to integrate new acquisitions at low cost and with low integration risk. Such technical capabilities
have also made us an attractive partner to third parties operating in our industry.

The following chart shows our centralized data analytics structure, under which we have centralized
global premium and carrier information using our data center based in Mullingar, Ireland:

We assign high priority to cyber security and have appointed a Chief Information Security Officer (the
“CISO”), who is supported in their activities by a dedicated information security team. The CISO’s
team is an independent risk and control team which ensures that our divisions maintain our desired
information security standards. As a result of our cyber security precautions, we have been able to obtain
insurance that provides coverage in the event of a cyber-attack.

**Intellectual Property**

We believe each of our underlying businesses’ trademarks and major service and product brands
enhance our competitive advantage and are essential to our business. Our businesses, in particular those
that are customer-facing and those with historic name recognition, have developed brand named
products and entities that we believe help attract and retain our customer base. We actively take steps

146


-----

to protect our intellectual property rights when and where we deem appropriate by relying on copyright
and trademark laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions. Many of our businesses
maintain their own trademarks and certain of our businesses market their products under a variety of
trademarks or brands. We have registered internet domain names, which are either used by our
businesses to deliver services and information to our customers or held to protect trading names and
brands that we develop. Although we have contributed to the development of certain of the software
platforms that we license, the proprietary rights in the intellectual property of these software platforms
generally rests with the licensors. We presently have no patents or patent applications pending.

**Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance (“ESG”)**

We strive to be a responsible industry presence seeking to contribute positively to society, industry
developments and the environment. We believe that a responsible approach to our employees, partners,
local communities, the environment and society in general is an essential part of our wider and longerterm success. We are committed to creating value for our stakeholders by embedding ESG
considerations throughout all stages of the insurance process. We have adopted a Sustainability Charter
based on five sustainability pillars. Our Sustainability Charter underpins all our conversations, business
decisions and the culture of our businesses. The five sustainability pillars of our Sustainability Charter
are outlined below.

- _Integrity. We seek to conduct our business in an honest and ethical manner._

- _Innovation. We seek to be proactive and responsive to our evolving client needs._

- _People. We seek to ensure the welfare of our employees and those we work with._

- _Society. We seek to enhance the wellbeing of the communities we serve._

- _Environment. We seek to protect the environment and become net zero._

We believe that we do not have any material environmental compliance costs or environmental
liabilities.

**_Integrity_**

Under the Integrity pillar, we are committed to upholding the highest ethical standards among our
executives, employees and business partners while addressing compliance and ethics risks related to
our business. It is our aim to ultimately cover strategies for ESG risk mitigation, business ethics,
management of the regulatory environment, critical incident risk management and systemic risk
management. Our primary policy for promoting integrity remains the Ardonagh Group Code of
Conduct. We also operate a dedicated, Group-wide Anti-Money Laundering and Anti-Bribery and
Corruption Program. This program includes due diligence on suppliers and vendors, annual training for
all personnel, requisite compliance declarations from all associated persons and comprehensive
whistleblowing arrangements. We have also become a signatory in support of the four principles of the
United Nations Principles for Sustainable Insurance (“UN PSI”). As a result, we are rolling out these
principles throughout our business to align our operations with the UN PSI common framework and
integrate ESG criteria into the wider business and into our stakeholder relationships.

**_Innovation_**

Under the Innovation pillar, we will continue to develop our understanding of our model’s resilience
and the innovation needed within the insurance sector to maintain a leadership position in the industry.
It is our aim to collaborate with partners on product development and lifecycle management aspects as
well as supporting initiatives to better manage the risks surrounding the physical impacts of climate
change, which could have a profound impact on insurability and pricing of certain assets or events,

147


-----

potentially rendering them uninsurable in the long run. In 2023, the Energy team at Price Forbes
designed and placed an insurance program to cover the construction of North America’s most
technologically advanced re-refiner. The re-refiner will aim to create a sustainable circular model for
oil. This technology is pioneering, and the energy team were pivotal in underpinning the success of the
project through the design of a comprehensive insurance program that de-risked the construction project
for its investors. The ability to aggregate portfolio data is much sought after for brokers and this
represents a firm endorsement of the data-powered strategy built by us. In July 2021 we launched a
Global Data and Risk Management Centre in Ireland. This management center delivers data-driven
insights to our clients worldwide, helping colleagues offer tailored solutions from our offices by
providing a highly diversified range of financial services-related products and services across the full
value chain and will drive innovation in the global financial services market and help further develop
one of the key risk research and development regions in Europe.

**_People_**

Under the People pillar, we continue to develop our employee-related practices, including those related
to their health and safety, and our initiatives relating to engagement, workforce equity, diversity and
inclusion. Fair treatment of our employees and the people we work with is crucial to the future continued
successful development of our business and the retention of highly skilled employees. We invest in
training and development and, following the COVID-19 pandemic, we have focused our efforts on the
mental and physical wellbeing of our employees. We believe in treating all people with respect and
dignity. We strive to create and foster a diverse, supportive, inclusive and understanding environment
in which all individuals can realize their maximum potential. We are committed to employing the best
people to do the best job possible, offering equal opportunities. The diverse capabilities that reside
within our talented workforce fulfil the needs of our industry to provide a high-quality service, and we
have taken a series of measures to encourage the promotion of diversity throughout our workforce and
in senior leadership roles. With respect to engagement, we use a collaboration and communication app
called “Engage” to connect all colleagues across the Group. We also set up an internal communication
called “Radio Ardonagh” to showcase achievements from across the Group and celebrate the successes
of colleagues.

We believe all our people should be able to access high quality learning, development, and engagement
opportunities, so they can realize their potential and enjoy successful and meaningful careers.
Throughout 2023 we have engaged with employees through targeted campaigns that promote subjects
relating to the Group’s well-established ED&I forums and wider colleague base. These have focused
on issues such as mental health awareness, support for communities through Give Back Week, Pride,
International Women’s Day and more. In April 2023, Ardonagh launched its bespoke Carbon Literacy
Training Programme, which was created and developed in-house in collaboration with the Carbon
Literacy Trust. This program aims to educate our employees on the actions they can take to reduce their
carbon footprint and to develop their own business specific projects to create greater climate awareness
at a local business level. The program was accredited by the Carbon Literacy Trust in June 2023 and is
being rolled out across the wider group via the learning and development team and the Sustainability
Champions forum.

We work with hundreds of companies across our supply chain, and expect our suppliers to meet high
standards in areas such as ethical conduct, human rights, workplace standards and the environment. We
have established due diligence processes to help select suppliers who meet these high standards. All our
employees are enrolled in our Group’s Diversity, Equality and Inclusion training module as part of their
annual training plan. We are working on deploying remuneration strategies to address the gender pay
gap.

148


-----

**_Society_**

Under the Society pillar, we aim to cover aspects of our business in relation to human rights and
community relations, customer privacy, data security, access and affordability, and selling practices and
product labelling. Treating customers fairly and looking after vulnerable customers have been industrywide priorities, particularly as millions of customers have tipped into ‘low financial resilience’. Poor
numeracy skills are seen as a big driver for these difficulties. Research, published in July 2021, found
that Plain Number versions of the same customer insurance documents, such as explanations of excess
or premium finance costs, doubled levels of understanding on average. Across five trials, customers
seeing the Plain Numbers versions were nearly twice as likely to be able to answer four out of five
comprehension questions correctly, thereby enabling them to make better decisions.

**_Environment_**

We are looking to play a more critical role in combating the climate crisis by better understanding,
managing and monitoring our greenhouse gas emissions, energy and water use as well as our waste and
ecological impact. We recognize that we have a responsibility to the environment and we endeavor to
be as environmentally friendly as possible in our business activities. We are committed to becoming net
zero and have developed a comprehensive environmental management program to guide our efforts in
our UK businesses. We continue to manage our waste and use of natural resources, and our consumption
of renewable energy is monitored. The below chart shows a breakdown of our greenhouse gas emissions

**Ardonagh Community Trust**

We believe it is important to support the communities that we live and work in. This belief led us to
establish the Ardonagh Community Trust (“ACT”) in 2018, a registered charity through which we
implement our community-focused charitable activities. To date, employees raised over £700,000 for
significant causes and ACT matched the effort with an additional £270,000, helping over 600 different
charities. Since its establishment, ACT has raised £5.5 million. Through a quarterly grant program, our
employees can also each access financial support of up to £5,000 for charitable causes and community
projects. In 2023, £66,000 was awarded in grants, helping 14 charities worldwide. Employees receive
one paid day a year to volunteer and support a charity or community project. We have also partnered
with leading mental health charities such as Mind, as well as Samaritans, which provides listening
services across the UK and Ireland for suicide prevention. Over £320,000 was raised for these two
partnerships. In 2024, ACT aims to partner with Médecins Sans Frontières, a global humanitarian
charity providing medical care around the world. We consider ACT to be one of our proudest
achievements, and we continue to be passionate about the communities we live and work in and believe
in the importance of supporting them in becoming stronger, better and brighter.
